Caution: Be sure to be realistic here: everyone pursuing an opportunity tends to be highly-optimistic about their venture and therefore usually end up overestimating the market size. Dean Kamen, the founder of Segway, in his enthusiasm for his invention was convinced that entire cities would be redesigned around the Segway. And, he was able to convince many investors, but that was not the case.
Definition: The "addressable market" is size of the market that is likely to have an interest in what you have to offer. It is that portion of the market that you are ready, willing, and able to serve.
Examples:
Mobile App Opportunity Example:

At first blush, many mobile app entrepreneurs claim an addressable market of one billion smartphones x $1/app for a $1 billion market opportunity. But it's imperative to get more specific. If the app is targeted at Road Warriors (business people that travel heavily) in the U.S. with links to U.S.-based travel and destinations sites, with app functionality that requires the use of location-based services, then the real addressable market is far smaller than $1 billion for a $1 app. And the market is even smaller if you are only focusing on one platform (such as the iPhone) as opposed to all smartphone platforms. See the example analysis below:

By the numbers:

  • # of U.S. Road Warriors (heavy business travelers):                     10.0 million (example data)
  • Multiply by the % of Road Warriors that carry smartphones:        x 95% (example assumption)
  • Equals the # of U.S. Road Warriors with smartphones:                = 9.5 million
  • Multiply by the % that use location-based services:                     x 74% (Pew Research) 
  • Equals the addressable market number of smartphone users:     = 7.0 million
  • Multiply by the price of the app:                                                    x $1.00/app
  • Equals the Addressable Market size of:                                       = $7.0 million

Services Business Example:

For purposes of an easy-to-understand example, let's use a lawn mowing business. To determine the addressable market size for a lawn mowing business that serves homeowners in your home town, start with the number of single family homes in your local area (the best source is probably the number of single family dwellings from the local tax rolls) and multiply that times the percentage of homeowners that are likely to hire someone to mow their lawn (if you don't know simply perform a quick survey of 25 random homeowners) and multiply that times the average number of mowings per year in your local area. Finally, multiply that result times the average price per mowing (if you don't know the price, call up two or three other lawn mowing services and ask them their price for an average size yard) to arrive at the market size in dollars. 

By the numbers:

  • # of local single family homes:                                10,000

  • Multiply by the % likely to hire out lawn mowing:     x 25%

  • Equals the # of homes likely to buy services:         = 2,500

  • Multiply by the average # of mowings per year:          x 40

  • Equals the # of mowings per year:                     = 100,000

  • Multiply by the average $ per mowing:                      x $30

  • Equals the Addressable Market size:               $3,000,000
Explanation:
When considering the addressable market size, keep in mind the following items: 

  • The overall market size based upon industry reports from industry trade organizations, government industry data or public company annual reports 
  • The size of the market segment for that portion of customers that are most likely to buy your product or service 
  • The size of the market geography you are ready, willing and able to serve (how far and wide are you going to range to serve customers?) 
  • The average price for your product or service 
  • For new product or service ideas, survey potential customers for additional data that may not be readily available 

Some common useful sources for frequent addressable market size searches:

  • All forms of technology and digital apps:
    • Comscore
    • IDC
  • Mobile app market:
    • Flurry
    • Nielsen Mobile
  • SaaS app market:
    • Information Age
    • Gartner
    • Forrester
  • B2B, B2C, retail, and eCommerce - Google Keyword Tool (to see the number of searches monthly for product and services)
  • Other good data sources:
    • U.S. Census Bureau (consumer and business data)
    • IRS tax stats (with data on Revenue by industry)
    • U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics (business and employment data)
    • U.S trade associations (they usually report on specific industry size and growth)
Key Principle: What is the size of that portion of the market that is likely to have an interest in the offering?
Key Question The Principle Is Asking: What is the size of the market for the offering?
Why This Matters:
The larger your potential market, the better the opportunity. The larger the market, the easier it will be for you to enter the market and carve out a sufficient amount of business in order to have a viable opportunity. 

A very small addressable market can be very problematic. For example, if the addressable market calcuations indicate $5m and taking a reasonable assumption that it is unlikely to enter a market and capture more than 10% market share, then the total potential Revenue for the opportunity is only $500k ($5m x 10% market share = $500k). Further, since a reasonable average Earnings for any opportunity is 10% of Revenue, that means the $5m addressable market would only produce a maximum Earnings of only $50k ($5m x 10% market share = Revenue of $500k x Earnings of 10% = $50k). Obviously that would not be a very exciting opportunity to pursue.
answer1: Very small addressable market size (<$5 million)
answer2: Small addressable market size ($5 million - $25 million)
answer3: Medium addressable market size ($25 million - $100 million)
answer4: Large addressable market size ($100 million - $1 billion)
answer5: Very large addressable market size (>$1 billion)
name: Addressable Market
right: A good example of a very large addressable market is a social media platform like Facebook that appeals to a core human need to stay connected and to communicate with others, especially those that are close to them. Not only does Facebook have broad, global appeal, but the more that users contribute to the platform, the more advertising value Facebook can glean from the user's information, so the overall size of Facebook's market opportunity grows naturally over time.
wrong: A negative example of an addressable market that was actually much smaller than anticipated was the Segway. Even though Segway exploded onto the scene with a huge amount of fanfare, massive amounts of capital, and all-star endorsements, the product found very little acceptance or interest from the general public. Instead, it is only a niche product used by a small percentage of postal workers, mall police, and a few other applications. The company and its management completely misread the addressable market and the vast majority of the global market had no intereste in a high-priced novelty.

Caution: Be sure to focus only on the organic growth rate of your specific addressable market and not the broader market by analyzing key geographic, demographic and psychographic profiles to tighten up your analysis.
Definition: The rate of annual growth of the addressable market. (There are other methods of growing an opportunity, such as market share growth and acquisition growth, but for purposes of analyzing the market in this principle, the "organic" growth is of the industry / market itself rather than different methods of growth compared to competitors.)
Examples:
Mobile App Opportunity Example:

If we stay with the example of the Road Warrior app we used in the Addressable Market analysis, then its critical that we ascertain the level of organic growth of our addressable market and not the broader smartphone market in general. For example, while the global smartphone pentration is exploding, that organic growth doesn't matter if we are targeting U.S.-based Road Warriors that are for the most part fully-penetrated. Since we can assume that most Road Warriors are heavy smartphone users, the germane focus would be the organic growth of the number of Road Warriors (most likely tied to overall economic growth of U.S. businesses) and certainly not the organic growth of smartphones.

Services Business Example:

Again, staying with the lawn mowing example introduced in the Addressable Market analysis, to determine the organic growth of the market for your home town lawn mowing business, first determine the number of new single family homes being built each year in your area and divide that number by the current number of single family homes to determine the amount of organic growth. For example, if there were 250 new homes built last year, (and assuming the 10,000 homes from our previous example) the organic growth is 250/10,000 = 2.5%.
Explanation:
When considering the organic growth of the addressable market for your opportunity, consider the following items: 

  • The overall market growth based upon industry reports from industry trade organizations, government industry data or public company annual reports 
  • The segment growth for the segment(s) of the market you serve (in our example, our target segment would be residential lawn mowing, rather than total landscaping services) 
  • The market growth within the geography you are ready, willing and able to serve (your addressable market) 

Some useful sources for market data that includes time series, trends, and other useful growth data:

  • All forms of technology and digital apps growth:
    • Comscore
    • IDC
  • Mobile app market growth:
    • Flurry
    • Nielsen Mobile
  • SaaS app market growth:
    • Information Age
    • Gartner
    • Forrester
  • B2B, B2C, retail, and eCommerce - Google Keyword Tool (to see the number of searches monthly for product and services over a series of months and years to ascertain growth trends)
  • Other good data sources:
    • U.S. Census Bureau (consumer and business data)
    • IRS tax stats (with data on Revenue by industry)
    • U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics (business and employment data)
    • U.S trade associations (they usually report on specific industry size and growth)
Key Principle: What is the rate of annual growth of the addressable market?
Key Question The Principle Is Asking: How fast is the addressable market growing?
Why This Matters:
The higher your organic growth, the better the opportunity. The faster the market grows, the easier it will be for you to grow your business as a rising tide lifts all boats.

A slow growth, no growth, or declining market means the industry and market compeitors not only find it impossible to grow -- except at each other's expense -- but the context will usually drive several other negative consequences such as price, gross margin, competitive intensity, etc.
answer1: Very low annual organic growth (<0%)
answer2: Low annual organic growth (0 – 5%)
answer3: Moderate annual organic growth (5 – 10%)
answer4: High annual organic growth (10 – 25%)
answer5: Very high annual organic growth (>25%)
name: Organic Growth

Definition: The extent to which technology plays a major role in shaping the market conditions and the competitive landscape; where a new and exciting technology can cause large changes in market share shifting from one competitor to another.
Examples:
Mobile App Opportunity Example:

While there are many business model advantages to mobile apps, this is one area of considerable risk for two primary reasons: 1) The near-continuous changes to mobile app platforms (from new types of smartphones and tablets introduced to the market, to new versions of existing mobile app operating systems) which can frequently require additional app upgrades and rewrites. 2) The steady stream of competing mobile apps that are creatively embracing new mobile app development tools, new partner app capability, etc. means a constant changing mix of technology availability that adds risk to the opportunity.

Services Business Example:

If a company has recently announced that it has developed a lawn mowing robot for less than $500 that automatically mows a lawn on the power of a rechargeable battery and if several other emerging companies have recently received venture capital investments to pursue a similar strategy, your lawn mowing business is threatened by a high degree of technological change that could have severe negative ramifications on the business. 

Examples of industries and markets with a high degree of technological change: 

  • The personal computer industry (think Moore's Law)
  • The mobile computing industry (smartphones and tablets as well as apps)
  • The software industry
  • Services industries with unusually high technology investment, such as financial services
  • Manufacturing industries with a high investment in technology-based capital equipment that serves a rapidly-advancing end-market, such as the nano-coatings industry where new coating materials and applications mean a constant upgrade of equipment to stay current
Explanation:
When considering the degree of technological change, consider the following items: 

  • Search the business press and industry trade journals to determine what kind of major advances have been announced in the past few years and what kind of innovations are currently being developed 
  • Search for venture capital investment announcements for your industry 
  • The type of technological change that potentially changes your customer's behavior creates more risk for your opportunity 
  • The type of technological change that dramatically lowers the cost of the product or service creates more risk for your opportunity 
  • If your opportunity is one that brings a new technology to market, then a low degree of technological change is still desirable because your new technology will get that much more attention and will not have to compete with a multitude of other new technologies
Key Principle: To what extent might new technology play a major role in shaping market conditions and market share of the addressable market?
Key Question The Principle Is Asking: How will changes In technology affect the opportunity?
Why This Matters: The lower the degree of technological change, the better the opportunity. The lower the degree of technological change, the less risk that technological innovation could render your offering obsolete in a short period of time.
answer1: Very high degree of technological change (>25% annual change to core technology infrastructure in the form of enhancements, new versions, or new apps)
answer2: High degree of technological change (15% to 25% annual change to core technology infrastructure in the form of enhancements, new versions, or new apps)
answer3: Moderate degree of technological change (10% to 15% annual change to core technology infrastructure in the form of enhancements, new versions, or new apps)
answer4: Low degree of technological change (5% - 10% annual change to core technology infrastructure in the form of enhancements, new versions, or new apps
answer5: Very low degree of technological change (<5% annual change to core technology infrastructure in the form of enhancements, new versions, or new apps)
name: Technological Change

Definition: The extent to which the ability to produce a product or service or the ability to sell a product or service depends on the time of year or season.
Examples:
Mobile App Opportunity Example:

While mobile apps would not have any seasonal limitations on the ability to deliver the app's functionality, the demand for some apps make spike seasonally compared to others based upon what drives customer demand for the app. For example, an app that tracks snow conditions on ski hills would typically be sold only in the winter time during ski season, while an app that tracks surfing conditions would typically be sold only in the summer time during peak surfing conditions.

Services Business Example:

If your lawn mowing business is located in a northern market that only has a six to eight month season, your revenue – and therefore earnings – will not be consistent throughout the year and potentially not enough to cover your costs in the off season. In addition, your assets will sit idle for four to six months out of the year and will not experience full utilization. 

Examples of other industries with a high degree of seasonality: 

  • Tourism 
  • Greeting card industry
Explanation:
When considering seasonality and its impact on the opportunity, consider the following items: 

  • Demand that ebbs and flows with seasonal changes based upon customer habits and buying patterns:
    • Season-specific products such as skiing equipment or outdoor furniture
    • Season-specific services such as landscaping or snow removal
    • Consumable products such as pool chemicals and lawn fertilizer
  • Ability to deliver the offering that ebbs and flows with seasonal changes:
    • Most agricultural production 
    • Yard care and landscaping services, including lawn mowing, snow removal, and exterior structure construction that can only be delivered in certain seasons
Key Principle: To what extent does the ability to produce or sell the offering depend on the time of year?
Key Question The Principle Is Asking: What affect will the time of year or seasons have on the opportunity?
Why This Matters: The less the seasonality, the better the opportunity. The less the seasonality, the more the potential for consistently higher asset utilization (for asset-intensive opportunities) and consistent Revenue and Earnings throughout the year (for any type of opportunity).
answer1: Very high seasonality (ability to produce or market demand limited to < 3 months per year)
answer2: High seasonality (ability to produce or market demand limited to 3 – 6 months per year)
answer3: Moderate seasonality (ability to produce or market demand for 6 – 9 months per year)
answer4: Low seasonality (ability to produce or market demand for 9 – 12 months per year)
answer5: Very low or no seasonality (ability to produce or market demand for 12 months per year)
name: Seasonality

Definition: The extent to which the target industry is subject to government regulation. Generally, the less the level of regulation, the better the opportunity. The less the level of regulation, the more the degrees of freedom for the management team to contiuously tweak its offering and business model.
Examples:
Mobile App Opportunity Example:

Presently there is very little regulation of mobile apps, but one example of a threat in some tax jurisdictions, is the threat of implementing a new tax on ecommerce. If so, that would be an example of an adverse regulatory environment that introduces additional costs and lowers current earnings.

Services Company Example:

If the lawn care industry is under constant scrutiny and laws are considered and often passed in each legislative session, the laws will typically only limit rather than expand the provider's business potential. If one year a law is passed that all lawn mowers needed to be switched from gasoline to electric (causing a massive industry reinvestment in assets) and the next year a law is passed that lawn care workers cannot be required to mow when the temperature is over 80 degrees and so forth, the lawn care industry would have become a target of lawmakers and there is a regulatory "environment" that will have a deleterious effect on the market. On the other hand, some regulation raises barriers to enter the market and limits competition, so while it may be harder for you to enter the market, it will limit the entry of other new competitors.

Examples of industries with a high regulatory environment: 

  • The pharmaceuticals industry (in which regulation can mean product development and approval pipelines of up to 10 years long, with unforseen changes along the way) 
  • The financial services industry, including credit card, mortgage, banking, insurance and brokerage (think of the many frequent changes in recent years in the U.S. on foreclosure laws and processes that adds a high degree of uncertainty to the foreclosure process)
  • The healthcare industry with either unclear interpretations of recent legislation and/or frequent changes to clarify and correct legislation that make it much more difficult to plan and execute on a give business model
Explanation:
When considering the regulatory environment and its impact on your target industry, consider the following items: 

  • Search the business press and industry trade journals to determine what kind of regulation may have been passed recently or is under consideration and consider what impact it may have on your business 
  • Look for whether or not the industry association has a regulatory "watch" newsletter or email bulletin that warns of potential harmful regulation 
  • Investigate the industry association's lobbying efforts and budget to get a feel for the level of effort to fend off regulation 
  • Industries that are flooded with legal forms are generally highly regulated and industries that tout licensing and certifications are generally highly regulated 
  • Be on the lookout for any kind of special industry taxes that may impact your business 
  • Some regulation will limit competition by raising barriers to market entry, thereby benefitting established businesses that have a limited number of competitors.
Key Principle: To what extent is the industry subject to government regulation or laws that affect price or demand?
Key Question The Principle Is Asking: How will regulation impact the opportunity?
Why This Matters: The less the regulation, the less the potential for unfavorable laws being passed that curtail demand or that unnecessarily drive up costs.
answer1: Very high regulatory environment (major regulatory reform pending/recently put in place and major governmental licensing or oversight)
answer2: High regulatory environment (minor regulatory actions pending or recently put in place with some governmental licensing or oversight)
answer3: Moderate regulatory environment (a few annual changes to the industry laws and procedures with some government oversight)
answer4: Low regulatory environment (very few annual changes and no government oversight of the industry)
answer5: Very low or no regulatory environment (virtually no regulation and no government intervention or oversight of the industry)
name: Regulatory Environment

Definition: The extent to which major trends in customer behavior or demographics play a critical role in shaping the market conditions and customer demand.
Examples:
Mobile App Opportunity Example:

There are a number of favorable macro trends affecting the mobile app market in general such as the fact that more and more webpages are served up on mobile devices, the fact that smartphone manufacturers and putting more and more power and computing capacity into their devices, and the fact that the general growth in mobile primes specific addressable markets to more readily adapt a mobile app.

A potential negative macro trend is the product line proliferation of screen sizes and operating systems of various smartphones and tablets that may potentially require additional optimzation and development around the increasingly myriad of devices.

Services Business Exampe:

If more and more homeowners in your addressable market are opting for synthetic grass that never needs to be mowed, this is a highly unfavorable macro trend that shrinks your market size and therefore limits your business opportunity. 

Examples of Other Favorable Macro Trends: 

  • Health care insurance brokers benefit from the macro trend of rapidly rising health care costs, since their percentage-based commissions rise dramatically each year even without adding any new customers, whereas all businesses suffer from the same macro trend due to their employee health care benefit cost 
  • Cell phone manufacturers benefit from the macro trend of users trading up cells phones for an additional popular "in-demand" feature 
  • As more and more consumers began using the Internet in the late 1990’s and early 2000’s, they began consuming their news more and more via the Internet and less and less via network television and printed newspapers, thus creating a negative macro trend for the old media companies and a positive macro trend for the new media companies.
Explanation:
When considering the favorability of macro trends, consider the following items: 

  • To determine macro trends and their potential impact on an industry, search consumer reports for consumer trends and the business press and industry trade journals for business trends 
  • Read the trade journals for your target industry for the past 24 months and look for announcements and articles discussing industry trends
Key Principle: To what extent do major trends in customer behavior or demographics shape market conditions and demand?
Why This Matters: These “macro trends” are major trends that tend to affect the entire industry and typically come in the form of trends in customer behavior or customer demographics, but can also stem from slowly shifting dynamics in the industry that are detected over a period of years that are not related to growth, technology, seasonality, or regulation. The more favorable the macro trend, the better the opportunity. The more favorable the macro trend, the more the potential demand for your offering.
answer1: Very unfavorable macro trends (2 or 3 trends that negatively affect the target market)
answer2: Unfavorable macro trends (1 trend that negatively affects the target market)
answer3: Neutral macro trends (no identifiable trends that affect the target market)
answer4: Favorable macro trends (1 trend that favorably affects the target market)
answer5: Very favorable macro trends (2 or 3 trends that favorably affect the target market)
name: Other Macro Trends

Definition: The amount of market share concentrated among the largest competitors within an industry; an indication of the market power of the largest competitors.
Examples:
Mobil App Opportunity Example:

To determine the degree of competitor concentration for mobile apps is considerably easier. You can search the app store and see the apps that are directly competing to solve the same problem and you can usually track down how many downloads they've had and/or their ratings. If you are targeting a niche that is dominating by a very popular app that is already widely adopted by many smartphone users, you are targeting a highly concentrated app target that will be difficult to gain traction vs. targeting an app to solve a problem where few apps exist or many apps that have not yet gained significant share of the addressable market according to your earlier market size calculations.

By the numbers:

  • # of downloads and purchases of the five most popular competing apps:   1.0 million
  • Divide by the # of smartphone users in the addressable market:              ÷ 7.0 million
  • Equals the competitor concentration:                                                         14.3%

Services Business Example:

To determine the degree of competitor concentration for your addressable market such as a lawn mowing business that serves homeowners in your home town, start with the number of competitors in your home town and try to identify the largest five. Estimate the number of homes they collectively serve (often their sales literature will give you clues or call them and ask them -- they will usually be eager to tell you) and divide that by the total number of homes that are likely to hire someone to mow their lawn (the addressable market). This represents the percent market share of the largest five competitors, an excellent indication of the degree of concentration.

By the numbers:

  • # of single family homes served by the five largest competitors combined:   500
  • Divide by the addressable market size (see 1 above):                              ÷ 2,500
  • Equals the competitor concentration:                                                        =     20%

Many industries that have experienced a high degree of consolidation and M&A activity (and often are also capital intensive industries) will have a high competitor concentration, such as:

  • Automotives
  • Airlines
  • Defense
  • Database software
  • ERP software
  • Telecommunications
Explanation:
When considering the degree of competitor concentration, consider the following items: 

  • Use estimates where there is imperfect market information 
  • Use telephone surveys of prospective competitors -- receptionists are usually more than happy to explain how successful a company is in the marketplace 
  • Look at websites, LinkedIn profiles, advertisements, sales literature, annual reports and other similar information for indications of size or market share 
  • One large competitor with high market share and many small competitors is still a highly consolidated market and therefore has a high degree of concentration
Key Principle: What is the market share concentration among the five largest competitors in the addressable market?
Why This Matters: The less concentrated the addressable market, the better the opportunity. Having fewer powerful competitors and more smaller competitors is a better context for a new entrant. The less concentrated the marketplace, the easier it is to enter the market and compete against the existing competitors that lack concentrated market power.
answer1: Very high degree of competitor concentration (top 5 control >80% market share or largest controls >40% market share)
answer2: High degree of competitor concentration (top 5 control 50 – 80% market share or largest controls 25 - 40%)
answer3: Moderate degree of competitor concentration (top 5 control 25 - 50% market share or largest controls 15 - 25%)
answer4: Low degree of competitor concentration (top 5 control 10 - 25% market share or largest controls 5 - 15%)
answer5: Very low degree of competitor concentration (top 5 are not identifiable or control <10% market share and the largest is not identifiable or controls <5% market share)
name: Competitor Concentration

Definition: The intensity with which the addressable market competitors compete with each other over customers.
Examples:
Mobile App Opportunity Example:

As most smartphone and tablet users can readily attest, there is significant churn in the app market. Users are quick to buy a cheap app and give it a try, only to delete it shortly afterwards it is doesn't provide sufficient value. Why this behavior may not has a significant impact on an app business model that is merely selling an app for $1, but it does if the business model depends upon in-app purchases, upsells, or a recurring revenue model. The customer satisfaction scores in the app market can serve as a fair proxy to the level of satisfaction and churn levels.

Services Business Example:

If the lawn care industry experiences intense competitive rivalry by constantly attacking each others customer base through aggressive marketing and price promotions in order to grow their business at the expense of their competitors, their overall marketing costs will rise, their customer life will shorten, their prices will go down, margins will shrink and overall the entire industry will suffer. Even though the industry suffers under such competitive rivalry, this kind of cutthroat rivalry often continues for extended periods of time - much like an arms race - once it begins. Look for signs of significant promotion of competing service in your target market in terms of the level and frequency of door hangers, promotional flyers, etc.

By the numbers:

  • # of expected customers lost per year:                                         5 
  • Divide by the customer base (# of expected customers):      ÷ 100 
  • Equals the Customer Churn:                                                       5%

Examples of industries with a high level of competitive rivalry: 

  • The competitive utility industry such as long distance, internet, mobile phone service, and electricity (look at the amount of promotional mailing you receive or the ads you hear/see in the media)
  • The credit card industry
Explanation:
When considering the degree of competitive rivalry and its impact on your target industry, consider the following items: 

  • Look at the level of customer churn (based upon the percent of the base amount of customers that leave each year) 
  • Compare the industry margins and earnings with other industries as a potential indication of competitive rivalry 
  • Look at the marketing and promotional activity as a potential indication of competitive rivalry 
  • Look for price or service promises such as lowest price guarantees
Key Principle: What is the level of intensity with which the competitors in the addressable market compete with each other?
Why This Matters: The less the competitive rivalry, the better the opportunity. The less the competitive rivalry, the higher the margins tend to be in the industry as competitors invest in their current customers and reap the benefits of longer-term customer relationships rather than fighting over them.
answer1: Very high competitive rivalry (> 15% customer churn)
answer2: High competitive rivalry (10% - 15% customer churn)
answer3: Moderate competitive rivalry (5% - 10% customer churn)
answer4: Low competitive rivalry (2.5% - 5% customer churn)
answer5: Very low competitive rivalry (< 2.5% customer churn)
name: Competitive Rivalry

Definition: The amount of supplier market share concentrated among the largest suppliers in the addressable market; an indication of the market power of the largest suppliers.
Examples:
Mobile App Opportunity Example:

There are two primary inputs into producing and selling mobile apps: the mobile app development and the app store. While the actual app development is not at all concetrated with tens of thousands of developers worldwide vying for your app development project on crowd sourcing sites such as eLance and oDesk, unfortunately the app stores by providers such as Apple and Google's Android app store have a lock on distribution and extract a hefty 30% revenue share with total control over the market. For example, Apple could raise the fee to 40% overnight, Google would likely match and the app entrepreneur loses 10% of Revenue without even a fight. This situation means mobile apps score low on this principle with a "High Degree of Supplier Concentration" due to having only a few highly-concentrated suppliers/providers with virtually no substitute for distribution.

Services Business Example:

To determine the degree of supplier concentration for the inputs or factors that you need for a lawn mowing business, start with identifying your variable cost inputs such as labor and gasoline and consider the ready source of supply from among the viable suppliers for those inputs. Since there is a gas station on nearly every corner and a ready supply of day laborers in most markets, a lawn care business usually enjoys a very high score on this principle due to the very low degree of supplier concentration.

Other Examples of High Supplier Concentration: 

  • The personal computer industry and the necessity to buy operating system and desktop software from Microsoft, the dominant software supplier 
  • Portions of the healthcare industry and the necessity to buy certain drugs or therapies that only have one supplier
  • The airline industry with only a few choices on engines and engine repair. (Consider Southwest Airlines. While it has wisely chosen only one engine type for its entire fleet to simplify its training, logistics, and repair processes, which enables it to score high on Operational principles, the company has put itself in a situation of having only one engine supplier. It's able to balance the negotiation power due to its large fleet and purchase volume, but a much smaller airline would experience significantly more supplier pain as the supplier extracts a premium given the high concentration of power.)
Explanation:
When considering the degree of supplier concentration, consider the following items: 

  • Start with the largest inputs into your variable cost by percentage 
  • Research the available sources of supply 
  • Look for the availability of substitute inputs 
  • One large supplier of a critical input with high market share and many small suppliers is still a highly-consolidated supplier market and therefore has a high degree of supplier concentration
Key Principle: How much of the variable cost structure is highly concentrated among only a few suppliers in the addressable market?
Why This Matters: The less concentrated the suppliers in your potential market, the more "competitive" the suppliers and the better the opportunity. The less concentrated the suppliers, the easier it will be for you to negotiate favorable supplier costs such as raw materials or input costs for your offering from suppliers that lack concentrated market power.
answer1: Very high degree of supplier concentration (50% or more of the variable input costs are only available from < 3 suppliers)
answer2: High degree of supplier concentration (25 - 50% of the variable input costs are only available from < 3 suppliers)
answer3: Moderate degree of supplier concentration (10 - 25% of the variable input costs are only available from < 3 suppliers)
answer4: Low degree of supplier concentration (5 - 10% of the variable input costs are only available from < 3 suppliers)
answer5: Very low degree of supplier concentration (all inputs are readily available and interchangeable from > 3 suppliers)
name: Supplier Concentration

Definition: The costs involved in switching from one supplier to another in the addressable market. The lower the switching costs, the better the opportunity. The lower the switching costs, the easier it is to switch suppliers if desired.
Examples:
Mobile App Opportunity Example:

There can be significant switching costs for an app entrepreneur with limited resources that built an iPhone app without the time and money to build an Android or other OS app. Because iOS app development is a proprietary platform, the app would need to be redevloped from scratch in order to switch over to the Android / Google Play app store. In that case, the switching costs can be high.

Services Company Example:

To determine the level of switching costs between suppliers in your lawn mowing business, start with identifying your variable cost inputs such as labor and gasoline and consider the costs to switch from one supplier to another. Since the need to train your labor is low, then your switching costs from one employee to another is very low (that explains the preponderance of "day laborers" that work in the lawn care industry) and since gasoline is a highly standardized commodity, there is virtually no switching costs from one supplier of gasoline to another.

Examples of industries with high switching costs: 

  • Airlines (such as Southwest discussed in the previous principle) that purchased certain engines for their airframes and built repair facilities for those engines have high switching costs to other engine suppliers. It would be virtually impossible for Southwest to switch. 
  • Information processors and service bureaus that purchased IBM mainframes that required licensing IBM software had high switching costs to other computing platforms
  • PC users have high switching costs to a Mac in the form of the learning curve in addition to the need to buy a new computer
Explanation:
When considering the supplier switching costs, consider the following items: 

  • Generally, the more standardized the inputs (labor, raw materials, etc.), the lower the switching costs 
  • Generally, the more proprietary or customized the inputs, the higher the switching costs 
  • Any kind of majors platform or infrastructure investment from a particular supplier usually carries significant switching costs 
  • The availability of alternative suppliers – if your switching costs are low, but there are no good alternatives, then low switching costs will have little impact on your cost equation
Key Principle: What are the costs involved in switching from one supplier to another?
Why This Matters: The lower the switching costs, the easier it will be for you to negotiate favorable input costs for your product or service from among the various suppliers with the real threat of switching to a different supplier and without being held captive by your current supplier.
answer1: Very high supplier switching costs (>200% of total monthly supplier cost)
answer2: High supplier switching costs (100% - 200% of total monthly supplier cost)
answer3: Moderate supplier switching costs (50% - 100% of total monthly supplier cost)
answer4: Low supplier switching costs (25% - 50% of total monthly supplier cost)
answer5: Very low supplier switching costs (<25% of total monthly supplier cost)
name: Supplier Switching Costs

Definition: The total size of the investment or capital required to buy or build the company, fully develop the opportunity, launch the new product, or fully fund the business plan.
Examples: To determine the total investment amount required, create a detailed financial model that includes various realistic scenarios and growth trajectories along with the funding required to achieve break-even as well as cost estimates for the assets for each major "unit" of production or service delivery. Alternatively, if you plan on acquiring a business, be sure to include all the transaction costs for the deal team (attorney, accountant, broker, etc.) as well as the initial working capital requirements and the purchase price of the business.
Explanation:
When considering the total investment amount required for your potential opportunity, consider the following 

items: 

  • An optimistic entrepreneur will typically underestimate the time and money required for a new opportunity
  • For startuips, the less the entrepreneur invests relative to other investors, the less ownership and control for the entrepreneur

Key Principle: What is the total investment required to fully fund the opportunity?
Why This Matters: The smaller the total investment amount required, the better the opportunity. The smaller the total investment amount required, the more likely the opportunity will get funded (either by your personal resources, company resource, or other investors), the more likely the entrepreneur will retain control and the less the risk for the entrepreneur and investors.

Definition: The total size of the investment required to assemble the fixed assets needed to operate the business relative to the total investment required to execute on the opportunity.
Examples: The Fixed Asset investment required should be already included in your detailed financial model that estimates assets required for each major "unit" of production or service delivery. A major "unit" of service delivery for a lawn mowing business, for example, may be one "crew" which includes one truck, one trailer, two mowers, two edger/trimmers, two rakes and one mower with a total investment cost of several thousand dollars for good used equipment.
Explanation:
When considering the fixed asset investment required, consider the following items:

  • The more the investment in fixed assets, the greater the risk of asset utilization and return on assets
  • The more specialized the fixed asset, the more the risk of the investment
  • Even though the concept of asset leverage is extremely powerful, asset leverage that involves highly specific assets should only be attempted once the other risks have been mitigated (operational risk, product and service risk, sales pipeline risk, market risk, etc.)
Key Principle: What portion of the total investment will be invested in fixed assets?
Why This Matters: The smaller the fixed asset investment required, the better the opportunity. The smaller the fixed asset investment required, the less risk of not being able to repurpose your investment or change direction with your business opportunity, since fixed assets can be difficult to use for other purposes and rarely retain a high resale value.
answer1: Very large fixed asset investment required (>60% of the total investment amount)
answer2: Large fixed asset investment required (40 - 60% of the total investment amount)
answer3: Moderate fixed asset investment required (20 - 40% of the total investment amount)
answer4: Small fixed asset investment required (10 - 20% of the total investment amount)
answer5: Very small fixed asset investment required (<10% of the total investment amount)

Definition: The average amount of elapsed time between when you experience the costs of the product or service you are delivering and when you collect from your customer for the product or service.
Examples:
Mobile App Opportunity Example:

While mobile apps can have a significan upfront development cost, there is no labor or materials input into each incremental unit ahead of demand and the revenue share paid to the app store is simultaneous to the cash collected from the sale to the customer.

Services Business Example:

The efficiency of the cash cycle in a lawn mowing business depends mostly on when you can get your customers to pay for your service. If you mow your customer's yards weekly and then bill them at the end of the service month and collect during the following month, you have a very inefficient cash cycle (30 - 60 days have elapsed prior to being paid) and your working capital requirements will continue to grow as you grow your business. On the other hand, if you bill your customers at the beginning of the month for that month's service and you collect during the month of service, you have an efficient cash cycle and you can grow the business without growing your working capital requirements since the cash coming in the door matches the timing of your cost of performing the service. 

Other Examples:

  • Efficient cash cycle: Any e-commerce company such as Amazon.com that collects the proceeds from the purchasers credit card prior to paying the book printers and FedEx (this does not hold true for companies that maintain inventory) 
  • Inefficient cash cycle: Any auto manufacturer or tract home builder that are producing autos and homes ahead of demand and placing them in inventory in thee hopes of selling them. These types of business models have high costs of labor and materials well ahead of realizing any cash from the sale of the car or home
Explanation:
When considering the cash cycle efficiency, consider the following items: 

  • Map out the typical customer engagement to determine when cost outlays begin and when the customer typically pays
  • Look for work in progress funding requirements based upon how long it takes to produce a product or service from start to finish 
  • Look for large amounts of debt on the Balance Sheets of peer companies in your target industry as an indication of inefficient cash cycles
  • Calculate the working capital requirements of the opportunity by subtracting the Current Liabilities from the Current Assets
  • Calculate the Days Outstanding on the Balance Sheet
Key Principle: What is the average amount of elapsed time between when you start to experience the costs of delivering the offering to a customer and when you collect from that customer?
Why This Matters: The more efficient the cash cycle (the faster you get paid), the better the opportunity. The more efficient the cash cycle, the more cash flow is generated and the less the need for external financing for working capital and growth.

Caution: For non-recurring businesses, the number of customers and Revenue will typically bounce around and even though the opportunity may breakeven in month five according to the plan, the reality is typically that the results will go up and down for several months prior to being solidly on pace with the sales and marketing process to achieve sustainable breakeven results.
Definition: The amount of time it takes for your opportunity to breakeven from the time you launch until your net income is zero or positive.
Examples:
Mobile App Opportunity Example:

If you have fixed monthly costs of $25,000 and your gross margin on each app sale is $0.69 ($0.99 less the 30% Revenue share), their your breakeven point = 36,232 apps. And, if according to your business plan and sales forecasts, it will take three months ramp up to over 36k app sales/month, then your breakeven timing is four months as you should breakeven the month following when you finally grew to the sufficient number of app dowloads.

Services Business Example:

If you have fixed monthly costs of $1,500 and your gross margin on each mowing is $15, then your breakeven point is $1,500/$15 = 100 mowings. And, if according to your business plan and sales forecasts, it will take six months to grow to 25 customers with an average of 4 mowings each, then your breakeven timing is seven months, as you should break even the month following when you finally acquired the sufficient number of customers. 

Other Examples:

  • Example businesses with a short breakeven timing: generally any service business with low fixed costs and where the only major input is the entrepreneur's time and talent such as a consulting business 
  • Example businesses with a long breakeven timing: generally any product business with high fixed costs and long product development timeframes such as enterprise software or drug therapies
Explanation:
When considering the breakeven timing, consider the following items: 

  • Most acquisitions should be above breakeven at closing unless the acquistion is a turnaround
  • The breakeven timing is highly dependent on the level of fixed costs and the success of the sales pipeline 
  • Research other opportunities in the target industry to ascertain average breakeven timing 
  • Many new product launches are halted due to uncertain or lengthy breakeven timelines due to slow launch growth that is forecasted to take too long to recover continued launch and promotion expenses
  • Build a detailed sales forecast and financial model using conservative projections to estimate sales growth, cost structure, and breakeven timing
Key Principle: How long will it take for the opportunity to have sufficient monthly revenue to cover all of its monthly expenses?
Why This Matters: The shorter the breakeven timing, the better the opportunity. The shorter the breakeven timing, the less the risk of opportunity failure due to not ever reaching breakeven.
answer1: Very long breakeven timing (> one year)
answer2: Long breakeven timing (six months – one year)
answer3: Moderate breakeven timing (three months – six months)
answer4: Short breakeven timing (one month – three months)
answer5: Very short breakeven timing (< one month)
name: Breakeven Timing

Definition: The costs that stay constant and do not vary based on the quantity of the number of offerings or the general level of Revenue.
Examples:
Mobile App Opportunity Example:

Many mobile app opportunities are simply a developer working from home with no additional overhead or fixed expenses other than living expenses already in the living budget, but for larger operations with an office and employees, fixed expenses will include all of the occupancy expenses from rent to utilities to repairs, all employee expenses for the minimum amount of staffing regardless of Revenue, etc.

Services Business Example:

The level of fixed costs for a lawn mowing business will generally be fairly low since most of the costs should be variable inputs such as labor and gasoline. The only fixed costs in a small lawn mowing business are likely to be facilities occupancy expenses (unless the business is run out of the home like many lawn mowing businesses), business liability insurance, and any equipment payments such as debt service for the equipment purchases. 

Examples of Opportunities with High Fixed Costs: 

  • Manufacturing businesses with a high fixed asset base such as buildings and manufacturing equipment carry high fixed costs whether they are producing or sit idle 
  • Agricultural enterprises with a high fixed asset base such as land, machinery, buildings, and fences carry high fixed costs whether they are producing or idle

Examples of Opportunities with Low Fixed Costs: 

  • Internet ventures tend to have a low fixed asset base, especially if they don’t build their own hosting infrastructure, which converts that item from a fixed to a variable cost
  • Services ventures such as consulting services that are operated out of a home with few cost inputs other than the consultant's time
Explanation:
When considering the level of fixed costs, consider the following items: 

  • The minimum level of expenses if there were no offerings for the month
  • Carefully plan for all fixed expenses such as minimum vendor or provider payments regardless of volume
  • Look for G&A and other overhead costs on the Income Statements of peer companies to get a sense for the average level of Fixed Costs in the target industry
Key Principle: What is the level of fixed costs expressed as a percentage of the total cost structure?
Why This Matters: Fixed costs typically include costs such as rent, debt payments, lease payments, insurance, salaries of supervisory personnel, etc. The lower the level of fixed costs, the better the opportunity. The lower the level of fixed costs, the shorter the breakeven timing and the less the level of sales required to be profitable.
answer1: Very high level of fixed costs (> 50% of the total cost structure)
answer2: High level of fixed costs (40% - 50% of the total cost structure)
answer3: High level of fixed costs (40% - 50% of the total cost structure)
answer4: Low level of fixed costs (20% - 30% of the total cost structure)
answer5: Very low level of fixed costs (<20% of the total cost structure)

Definition: Gross Margin is the difference between the Net Sales Revenue and the Direct Expenses (also known as Variable Expense) such as the cost of goods sold (COGS) and any Direct Labor expenses. Gross margin is also commonly referred to as Gross Profit and is usually expressed as a percentage as follows: (Net Sales Revenue - Direct Expenses) / Net Sales Revenue. Therefore, $100 of Net Sales Revenue with Direct Expenses of $50, results in a Gross M of 50%. Gross Margin is often measured on a unit of sales (unit Gross Margin) as well as a total Gross Margin for a given period.
Examples:
Mobile App Opportunity Example:

Most mobile apps are sold in an app store with only one Direct Expense of a Revenue share of 30% to the app store owner such as Google or Apple. If so, the Gross Margin is generally 70% if the Gross Sales Revenue is booked, e.g. the total listed price of the app. However, if the Net Sales Revenue is booked because the app store collects the customer payment and then pays the mobile app company to Net Sales Revenue after the Revenue share is subtracted, then the Gross Margin is generally 100%.

Services Business Example:

To calculate the unit Gross Margin of a lawn mowing business, calculate the Gross Margin of each "unit" of service, or each mowing. If the average price is $30 per mowing and the Direct Expenses are $2 for gas and $13 of Direct Labor, then the unit Gross Margin is $15 or 50%.

Other Example Gross Margins:

  • Example opportunities with low Gross Margins: Any heavy manufacturing company with high labor and materials content, many of which struggle to achieve a Gross Margin above 25% - 35%
  • Example opportunities with high Gross Margins: Software business models with very low content cost in terms of materials or labor and information services business models with highly automated processes that translate into low labor and materials content
Explanation:
When considering the Gross Margin, consider the following items: 

  • Look at the average Gross Margin of peer companies or similar opportunities
  • Calculate the Gross Margin of the historical financial results or the business plan
  • Look for trends in overall Gross Margin as well as the Gross Margin by offering type to ascertain which offerings have the best and worst Gross Margin
  • The mix of products and services in the overall offering will affect the overall average Gross Margin, i.e. if you sell more low Gross Margin items compared to high Gross Margin items in a particular period, your overall Gross Margin will decline 
  • Low Gross Margin businesses such as grocery and retail or distribution companies can still be nicely profitable if they have high "velocity" or a high number of inventory "turns" per year
Key Principle: What is the anticipated Gross Margin of the average offering?
Why This Matters: Opportunities with high Gross Margins will generally always perform better on all other financial metrics compared to opportunities with lower Gross Margins unless there are significant overhead or Indirect Expenses associated with the high Gross Margin business. Most of the world's most valuable businesses are enterprises that have business models that have high Gross Margins due to low Direct Expenses compared to Revenue.
answer1: Very low gross margin (< 20%)
answer2: Low gross margin (20% - 35%)
answer3: Moderate gross margin (35% - 50%)
answer4: High gross margin (50% -75%)
answer5: Very high gross margin (> 75%)
name: Gross Margin
