Definition: The return on the total investment in the fully-funded opportunity expressed as a multiple of the total investment that is allocated to the investor. The investor's value is based upon the investor's portion of the Equity Value, which is calculated as the Enterprise Value, less Debt, plus any excess Cash. (See the examples below.)
Examples:
Mobile App Opportunity Example:

To determine the return multiple of a ficticious mobile app company, let's assume that similar companies have sold for 1.5x Trailing Twelve Months (TTM) Revenue (instead of an Earnings multiple), you raised $1 million from angel investors for 40% of the company, your plan calls for the fifth year revenue to be $10 million, and your plan calls for no excess cash or debt at the end of five years. The return multiple for the angels investors would be calculated as follows:

  • Enterprise Value = $10 million of TTM Revenue x 1.5x Revenue = $15 million
  • Less Debt = $0
  • Plus excess Cash = $0
  • Equals an Equity Value of $15 million
  • x 40% ownership by the angel investors
  • Equals allocated Equity Value of $6 million
  • Divided by the Total Investment of $1 million
  • Equals a return multiple of 6x

Services Business Example:

To determine the return multiple for a lawn mowing business, let's assume that similar companies have sold for 3x Trailing Twelve Months (TTM) EBITDA, you personally invested $50k to get started, you own 100% of the business, your plan calls for the fifth year EBITDA to be $1 million, and your plan calls for no excess cash and $1 million of equipment debt at the end of five years. The return multiple for your initial investment would be calculated as follows:

  • Enterprise Value = $1 million of TTM EBITDA x 3.0x EBITDA = $3 million
  • Less Debt = $1 million
  • Plus excess Cash = $0
  • Equals an Equity Value of $2 million
  • x 100% ownership
  • Equals allocated Equity Value of $2 million
  • Divided by the Total Investment of $50k
  • Equals a return multiple of 40x
Explanation:
When calculating the Enterprise Value of the opportunity, consider the following items: 

  • Look for press releases from publicly held companies that have recently completed the acquisition of a private company for the earnings multiples of peer companies and opportunities
  • Look for announcements of acquisition deal terms in publicly traded companies' quarterly earnings reports or annual reports 
  • Look for acquisition analyses written up by industry trade journals 
  • Contact an investment banker that targets your industry and describe the type of company you are building and ask them if they have any research on typical earnings multiples -- they will typically have a research report with the data you need
  • Ask potential investors how they would value the opportunity upon an exit
  • For new product launches or internal inititatives, calculate the overall impact the opporunity will have on the Enterprise Value

When calculating the return multiple based upon the Equity Value of an opportunity, consider the following items:

  • Use a detailed financial model with conservative assumptions that calcualtes the return mulitple properly
  • Subtract any Debt and add any excess Cash (over and above the average working capital requirements) from the Enterprise Value
  • Allocate the Equity Value properly to the investor based upon the capitalization and ownership table to properly account for any dilution to the investor(s)
Key Principle: What is the five year return on the total investment in the opportunity?
Why This Matters: Investors such as private equity and venture capital investors and corporate development departments will only be attracted to opportunities that meet minimum returns on investment over a specific timeframe. Putting capital at risk will normally requires returns at higher rates that public equity returns. Most corporate product development guidelines will also have minimum hurdles in terms of the expected returns on a new product investment. And finally, entrepreneurs and business owners have limited time and focus and should only invest their time on the highest potential return opportunities.
answer1: Very low earnings multiple (< 3X)
answer2: Low earnings multiple (3X)
answer3: Moderate earnings multiple (4 - 5X)
answer4: High earnings multiple (6 - 7X)
answer5: Very high earnings multiple (> 7X)
name: Return on Investment

Definition: The risks that the opportunity will not be able to operationally deliver its offering due to uncontrollable risks such as weather, pests, supplier instability, labor instability, and/or political instability.
Examples:
Mobile App Opportunity Example:

A mobile app company selling downloadable apps in an app store has virtually no Operational Risks.

Services Business Example:

The primary Operational Risk of a lawn mowing company is weather, since lawns cannot be cut on rainy days. A rainy week can mean not being able to mow for the entire week and tougher mowing conditions that increasea the time to serve the next week, resulting in a loss of 25% of the monthly revenue for the month with the rainy week as well as higher labor costs the week following the rain. Even though the Revenue is lost, Indirect Expenses are still experienced and potentially Direct Labor still had to be paid at least some amount, resulting in a financial loss for any rainy day.

To calculate the impact of the weather risk on a lawn mowing business, look at the average number of rainy days for the addressable market and reduce the Revenue assumptions by that amount:

Example calculation:

  • Average # of rainy days = 25
  • Average # of work days = 312 (52 weeks x 6 days/week)
  • Percentage impact on Revenue = 25/312 = 8%

Other Example Opportunities with High Operational Risk: 

  • The airline industry that faces uncertainties in both weather that can delay or cancel flights (a loss of Revenue) as well as highly skilled labor that is not readily fungible and with a propensity to strike (a loss of Revenue and potentially an increase in Labor rates)
  • The agricultural industry that faces uncertainties in weather, pests and other natural causes (could lead to a 100% loss of Revenue x the probability of a dry year) - example, if a dry year happens 1 in 7 years and a dry year means a yield of only 50% of the average yield, then the rain risk = 1 / 7 x 50% = 7% of Revenue
  • An acquisition or investment in a country that has a history of political instability (such as military coups) or currency instability (such as rampant inflation)
Explanation:
When considering the type of operational risk of the opportunity, consider the following items and others like them that create high operational risk: 

  • Dependence upon uncontrollable weather or pest conditions, such as found in agricultural production or any outdoor services business that cannot be delivered on rainy days
  • Dependence upon unproven suppliers with little or no track record of success
  • Operating in a volatile or unstable political environment
  • Dependence upon unfavorable labor relations where labor has a propensity to strike or walkout (while the Labor Pool principle captures the cost of the labor pool, this risk is focused on the potential disruptions caused by labor)
  • Any other potential disruption or uncontrollable input into the offering
  • When calculating the degree of Operational Risk, calculate the total percent of Revenue or Cost that the combination of risk factors represent
Key Principle: What are the uncontrollable risks of the opportunity?
Why This Matters: The lower the operational risk, the better the opportunity. The lower the operational risk, the better the chances of being able to operate without disruption.
answer1: Very high operational risk (the combination of risks could impact >25% of the total costs or >50% of the Revenue)
answer2: High operational risk (the combination of risks could impact 10% to 25% of the total costs or 25% to 50% of the Revenue)
answer3: Moderate operational risk (the combination of risks could impact 5% to 10% of the total costs or 10% to 25% of the Revenue)
answer4: Low operational risk ((the combination of risks could impact up to 5% of the total costs or up to 10% of the Revenue)
answer5: Very low operational risk (there are no apparent risks)
name: Operational Risk

Caution: There is often the sense of a need to own and build the entire value chain of manufacturing, distribution, sales and marketing, etc., but that notion should be resisted. It is extremely hard to develop mutiple capabilities, perfect them, and operate them at scale in the early stages of an opportunity's launch. Be careful never to invest in infrastructure that already exists.
Definition: The number of distinct internal capabilities or different business processes you plan to develop as part of your offering.
Examples:
Mobile App Opportunity Example:

Most mobile app opportunities are solely focused on one capability: that capability of developing a killer app that solves a specific problem. The benefit of an app store such as Google and Apple is that the marketing, sales, and e-commerce capabilities are not required to be developed, making it much easier for the mobile app developer to focus on the one thing they do best.

Services Business Example:

Using our lawn mowing example, there are relatively few internal capabilities required (mowing and edging) and they are relatively simple to perfect, thereby resulting in a low risk profile.

Examples of Minimizing the Number of Core Capabilities:

Product design and branded goods firms such as kitchen utensil company OXO and lifestyle company Ralph Lauren Polo both focus on only two core internal capabilities: design and marketing (their core brand attributes). All manufacturing, distribution and retail sales are accomplished through partnering or external relationships.
Explanation:
When considering the number of internal capabilities needed for your potential venture consider the following items: 

  • Map out all processes and capabilities required to deliver your offering to customers
  • Identify which of those capabilities are strategically essential to the opportunity (critical for you to control, critical to your strategic advantage, critical for customer satisfaction, etc.) and which of those capabilities -- while still necessary -- are not strategicalloy essential but are instead more of a non-differentiating, generic process
  • Hint: non-core capabilities are often processes that are "sub-scale", i.e. too small for you to get a meaningful return out of creating or gaining the capability internally. In that case, it makes more sense outsource the capability
  • Prioritize the strategically essential capabilities
  • Consider focusing on first perfecting one capability profitably and then growing other capabilities as needed
  • Count capabilities based upon the groupings such as: offering design, offering development, offering manufacturing or operations or delivery, customer service, sales and marketing, finance and accounting, etc.
Key Principle: How many distinct internal capabilities are required to fully realize the opportunity?
Why This Matters: The fewer internal capabilities that are to be developed, the better the opportunity. The fewer internal capabilities that are to be developed, the lower the investment (in time and capital) and the lower the risk of the opportunity.
answer1: Very high number of internal capabilities (>6 capabilities)
answer2: High number of internal capabilities (5 – 6 capabilities)
answer3: Moderate number of internal capabilities (3 – 4 capabilities)
answer4: Low number of internal capabilities (2 – 3 capabilities)
answer5: Very low number of internal capabilities (1 capability)
how to improve 1: Reduce the number of internal capabilities through outsourcing or partnering with other firms that are experts in a particular capability and can perform that capability faster, cheaper and better than you can
name: Capability Development

Caution: Be sure to pilot with customers that demonstrate the broadest portion of the addressable market to get a large, representative sample of feedback and design input. For manufactured offerings, make use of contract manufacturers and prototype manufacturers prior to sinking capital into production facilities.
Definition: The ability to meaningfully test your product prototype or service with a representative sample of pilot or beta customers prior to investing the resources necessary to gear up for full production or launch.
Examples:
Mobile App Opportunity Example:

In general, mobile apps have a lower total investment than many opportunities and can therefore be fine tuned in the testing phase with pilot customers far easier than most software applications or other, more complex offerings or opportunities. Sufficient time should be allowed for the testing and modification process.

Services Business Example:

Using our lawn mowing example, the service is readily understood, but pilot customers will help formalize the procedures, fine-tune your processes, and close the gap between customer expectations and your service delivery. As a service business, it is also critical to have reference customers, which your test customers can become. 

Examples Where Pilots Are Critical: 

  • Any enterprise software product, due to the complexity of standardizing the automation of many custom processes 
  • Any new product design due to the need for user group feedback on the fitness for use of the product prototype and since the cost of final design specs and manufacturing processes are very expensive
Explanation:
When considering the ability to test prior to full development consider the following items: 

  • The need to test or pilot is not as critical for products or services of a commodity nature that vary little from other commonly available alternatives 
  • The need to test or pilot increases with the uniqueness of the value proposition, the level of total investment, and the level of fixed asset investment
  • Perform thorough customer surveys as a way to gather information prior to designing the offering 
  • Consider giving away the offering to initial pilot customers in exchange for their design feedback and marketing cooperation is an excellent way to partner with these important initial customers
  • Consider developing your offering in partnership with a large, initial customer prior to full commercialization
  • The need to pilot is not at all critical for acquistions of existing companies, but it is highly recommended that extensive customer satisfaction surveys be completed
Key Principle: What is the ability to fully test the offering with a representative sample of customers prior to launching the opportunity?
Why This Matters: The higher your ability to test or pilot prior to full development, the better the opportunity. The higher your ability to test or pilot prior to full development, the lower the investment and risk of the opportunity and the greater the chance to "reorient" or "pivot" your offering as necessary to better meet customer requirements.
answer1: Very low ability to pilot prior to full development (pilot/prototype cost is >75% of full development cost)
answer2: Low ability to pilot prior to full development (pilot/prototype cost 50% - 75% of full development cost)
answer3: Moderate ability to pilot prior to full development (pilot/prototype cost is 25% - 50% of full development cost)
answer4: High ability to pilot prior to full development (pilot/prototype cost is 10% - 25% of full development cost)
answer5: Very high ability to pilot prior to full development (pilot/prototype cost is <10% of full development cost or N/A)
name: Ability to Pilot

Caution: The time, effort, and cost to develop intellectual property is typically far greater than business plans forecast
Definition: The ability to develop a registered copyright, trademark, or patent around whatever may be proprietary about your product, process, or business that protects and extends the value of your business opportunity.
Examples:
Mobile App Opportunity Example:

Since the mobile app marketplace is to fast-paced an dynamic, it may not make sense to take the time (up to a year) and money ($25k to $50k) to try to patent any part of the app design or process unless there is a real breakthrough idea that had much broader implications.

Services Business Example:

Using our lawn mowing example, there is most likely little opportunity to create any type of intellectual property unless in the course of running the business you happen upon a great idea for the development of new mowing or lawn care technology, but normally services opportunities do not lend themselves to the creation of intellectual property. 

Example industries where intellectual property plays a major role: 

  • High technology (bio-technology, medical technology, network technology, software technology, circuit technology, etc.) 
  • Creative arts (books, movies, etc.)
Explanation:
When considering the ability to create intellectual property consider the following: 

  • For services businesses, look for the opportunity to inculcate best practices and create proprietary business processes 
  • For product businesses, research current patents and ascertain whether any of your proprietary products are patentable
  • Calculate the estimated percentage of the offering's design inputs or process that is made up of intellectual property that can be protected
Key Principle: What is the ability to develop a copyright, trademark, or patent the offering to extend the value of the opportunity?
Why This Matters: The more your ability to create and protect intellectual property, the better the opportunity. The more your ability to create and protect intellectual property, the more potential value your business opportunity will create through limiting competition, licensing, royalties, or other residual income.
answer1: Very low ability to create intellectual property (< 5% of the offering input or process is proprietary)
answer2: Low ability to create intellectual property (5% - 10% of the offering input or process is proprietary)
answer3: Moderate ability to create intellectual property (10% - 25% of the offering input or process is proprietary)
answer4: High ability to create intellectual property (25% - 50% of the offering input or process is proprietary)
answer5: Very high ability to create intellectual property (> 50% of the offering input or process is proprietary)
name: Intellectual Property

Definition: The relationship between the growth in units of each offering and the incremental cost of each offering. This principle is related to "economies of scale" and is defined as the ability to increase the number of units offered (either products or service engagements) and experience a decrease in the average cost of each unit.
Examples:
Mobile App Opportunity Example:

A typical mobile app is both highly repeatable (the same app) and highly scalable because once it is developed there is no additional labor or materials input cost for each incremental unit sold. There may be significant additional marketing or other overhead expenses, however, so the additional costs for incremental sales should include all costs to truly get a sense for total scability. If each $1k increase in sales requires a $300 increase in Revenue Share (because of a flat 30% Revenue Share to the app store) and a $250 increase in indirect sales and marketing expense, then each doubing in sales requires a 55% increase in expenses.

Services Business Example:

While a lawn mowing business is highly repeatable (the same offering of mowing and trimming) and will experience cost declines due to the Experience Curve as noted in the Repeatability section, it is not highly scalable. Each incremental mowing job still requires labor, gasoline, wear and tear, and other consumables. While the employees may get better with each repeated service due to repeatability, there is still significant Direct Expenses for each unit of offering. Given the fact that most of the cost inputs will consist of labor and fuel costs, neither of which get a volume discount, there are few economies of scale.

Other Examples:

Example industries with low scalability: 

  • Services-based business models with an inabilty to automate the service such as medical or legal specialty firms with unique expertise that require the recruiting and training of specific with long training and development programs prior to the individual being equipped to deliver the service 
  • Product-based business models with a significant amount of Direct Labor and COGS in each product (while spec or production home builders and automakers have high repeatability, their offerings are not scalable)

Example industries with high scalability: 

  • Telecommunications companies that can easily deliver nearly any level of service over their existing infrastructure and can easily plug in incremental capacity onto existing infrastructure 
  • Software companies that can easily sell an unlimited number of licenses once the software is developed, resulting in high scalability in terms of both cost and operations
  • Digital books, digital music, and streaming video with virtually no incremental labor input and very low COGS per unit (however there may be significant infrastructure investment or outsourced expense for hosting and e-commerce infrastructure)
Explanation:
When considering the scalability of your opportunity, consider the following items: 

  • Products such as packaged software, books, songs, and videos are usually highly scalable: once they are developed they can be sold to one customer or one million customers with very little additional input cost such as labor and materials - especially if it is directly downloadable
  • Calculate what level of additional inputs is required for each incremental sales unit
  • Calculate the relationship of Total Expenses (Direct and Indirect) to Revenue; look at both Gross Margin and EBITDA as the overall opportunity grows
  • While many offerings are repeatable (the same type of offering), they are not necessarily scalable (little additional cost input for each incremental offering unit)
Key Principle: How much does each incremental offering cost?
Why This Matters: High scalability means the Revenue grows faster than Direct Expenses. The more scalable the business model, the better the opportunity. The more scalable the business model, the higher the profitability and the higher the operating leverage.
answer1: Very low scalability (a doubling of sales requires a >75% increase in costs)
answer2: Low scalability (a doubling of sales requires a 50% to 75% increase in costs)
answer3: Moderate scalability (a doubling of sales requires a 25% to 50% increase in costs)
answer4: High scalability (a doubling of sales requires a 10% to 25% increase in costs)
answer5: Very high scalability (a doubling of sales requires a <10% increase in costs)
name: Scalability

Definition: The ability to sell the same product or service over and over again with the same product or process content in a cookie cutter fashion.
Examples:
Mobile App Opportunity Example:

Most mobile apps are completely repeatable where every customer downloads and uses exactly the same app. Although the cost of development goes up due to the need to create the apps in various operating systems such as Android and iOS, once developed, the repeatability is 100% for each app download and purchase. By contrast, a firm that creates custom mobile apps as a work for hire have very low repeatability (see the Other Examples below for more on this). 

Services Business Example:

Using our lawn mowing example, the service is highly repeatable in that you are performing the same basic service for all customers. If the same exact service of mowing and trimming is offered to every customer, there is 100% repeatability. By contrast, services companies that offer a customized service to each client do not have a repeatable process. 

Other Examples:

Example businesses with high repeatability: 

  • Packaged software (same software being sold over and over again) 
  • Production home building (same floor plan being built over and over again) 

 Example business with low repeatability: 

  • Custom software development (although some of the processes can be repeated, the actual work itself is of a one-off nature and is not repeatable). Even though the capability of developing software is the same as in packaged software, the business model of custom software does not have the same favorable characteristics of repeatabilty. 
  • Custom home building (again, although some of the processes can be repeated, the actual work itself is of a one-off nature and is not repeatable). Even though the capability of building homes is the same as in spec or production home building, the business model of custom home building does not have the same favorable characteristics of repeatabilty.
Explanation:
When considering the repeatability of your opportunity's offering, consider the following items: 

  • Can the offering be standardized sufficiently so that large numbers of customers receive the same offering specification and still have their needs met? 
  • If you do offer multiple offerings, do those variations cause major shifts in the production or service delivery requirements?
  • When calculating the level of repeatability, measure the percentage of product or process input into the offering that changes for each additional offering
Key Principle: What is the ability to sell the same offering to all customers?
Why This Matters: For a services business, this typically means the ability to use service templates or "productize services" in order to deliver the same consistent service over and over again. For a product business, this typically means the ability to produce and sell the same product many times over and to have less product line proliferation. The higher the repeatability of the offering the better the business model and the opportunity. The more customers that buy exactly the same offering, the quicker that offering can be perfected, the faster the organization can learn, the faster costs will decline, and the easier it is for the business to grow. Only opportunities with repeatable offerings can take advantage of the Experience Curve which has been proven that in nearly every business model, the cost of delivering any offering goes down by 20% - 30% for each cumulative doubling of output of that same offering. Think of it as practice makes perfect.
answer1: Very low repeatability (a doubling of sales requires a >75% change in the offering)
answer2: Low repeatability (a doubling of sales requires a 50% to 75% change in the offering)
answer3: Moderate repeatability (a doubling of sales requires a 25% to 50% change in the offering)
answer4: High repeatability  (a doubling of sales requires a 10% to 25% change in the offering)
answer5: Very high repeatability (a doubling of sales requires a <10% change in the offering)
name: Repeatability

Definition: The comparative cost of the skill sets that are required to grow the opportunity.
Examples:
Mobile App Development:

Software development has increasing become globally portable with lower-cost developers readily sought out via crowd sourcing websites, but be sure to add the necessary management and oversight effort to any outsourced/crowdsourced development labor. In addition to development, if application support and maintenance is a significant portion of the cost mix and you are hiring from a high-cost labor pool, then there will be labor pool issues that create disadvantages.

Services Business Example:

A typical local services opportunity such as lawn mowing usually draws nearly all of its labor from the same local labor pool as competitors and therefore should not experience any labor pool disadvantages. However if your opportunity is a services opportunity that serves remote customers and competes with other remote services companies, then there may be labor pool disadvantages.

Example Business Models with Labor Pool Issues: 

  • Operations that require many skilled "technicians" such as welders, assemblers and other craftsmen that are usually unionized into what is called Closed Shops, Union Shops or Agency Shops that compete with significantly lower-cost operations (such as the labor cost content of Chinese-manufactured goods v.s. U.S.-based manufactured goods produced in high-cost, unionized labor markets)
  • Operations that require many, highly-skilled, hard-to-replace employees such as airlines (where the bulk of their employees are highly-trained, licensed and certified pilots, flight attendants, and mechanics) that can suffer extreme cost penalties when negotitating with a labor pool that is not easily fungible or replaceable
Explanation:
When considering the favorability of the labor pool for the opportunity, consider the following items: 

  • Look for competitor/peer company comparisons and the labor cost variances, e.g., if the opportunity competes with firms that hire from substantially lower-cost labor pools in lower cost of living areas for similar skills sets, then your opportunity will be at a significant competitive disadvantage
  • Look for the opportunity to rationalize the cost of labor or shift it to lower-cost labor areas, whether with a direct worksforce or outsourced strategy
  • Labor pool characteristics vary widely from location to location, so check the local unemployment statistics to verify to availability of labor in general, but focus on the availability of the skills sets required as the opportunity scales 
  • Check online job boards and salary websites to get a sense for the cost of labor for the skill sets required in the area of the opportunity (and verify that the plan includes the correct cost assumptions) 
  • If the opportunity is an acquisition, verify whether or not the labor is unionized (22% of the U.S. labor force belongs to a union) as union labor usually carries a significantly higher labor rate that non-union labor rates
  • Look for the availability of the necessary skills that scale with the growth of the company, i.e. whatever skill set you have to hire the most of in order to grow the opportunity is the most critical part of the labor pool to focus on for purposes of the analysis
  • Hidden costs of labor may include the availability of the skills sets you require (you may have additional relocation or training expenses) and the comparative character traits of the labor pool (a labor pool that lacks punctuality and diligence carries an additional cost that may not be obvious without thorough analysis)
Key Principle: What is the cost the labor compared to competitors?
Why This Matters: The lower the overall cost of the majority of the labor required compared to competitors, the better the opportunity. The lower the overall cost of labor compared to competitors, the higher the comparative profitability and/or the lower the comparative cost of operations.
answer1: Very unfavorable labor pool costs (the bulk of the necessary labor costs >10% more than competitors)
answer2: Unfavorable labor pool costs (the bulk of the necessary labor costs 5% to 10% more than competitors)
answer3: Neutral labor pool costs (the bulk of the necessary labor costs roughly the same as competitors)
answer4: Favorable labor pool costs (the bulk of the necessary labor costs 5% to 10% less than competitors)
answer5: Very favorable labor pool costs (the bulk of the necessary labor costs >10% less than competitors)
name: Labor Pool

Definition: The ability to identify the needs of the potential customers in the addressable market and clearly determine whether or not those needs are currently under-served or not being met by the existing competitive offerings and substitutes.
Examples:
Mobile App Opportunity Example:

One of the challenges of uncovering unmet needs with mobile apps is to pinpoint where other offerings leave off and your offering picks up. There are many competitive apps and substitute apps that need to be analyzed to fully determine whether or not there are needs that are not fully met. Be sure to poll a broad enough sample to insure that the need is a real need vs. initial customer prospects that were simply unaware of other available offerings that would have adequately meet their needs.

Services Business Example:

Using our example of a lawn mowing business, the ability to discern your potential customers unmet needs should be high since you are serving a local, concentrated market. You can easily conduct door-to-door in-person surveys and you can even offer to provide the service free to make sure you do it the way they like it and in the process, you will have conducted very valuable market research while landing a new customer. 

Other Examples:

  • Opportunities that have a harder time uncovering unmet needs: businesses with customers that have an unpredictable and periodic need pattern, such as home and auto repair or emergency services that are rarely needed and difficult to identify target customers and difficult to engage them in a meaningful dialogue 
  • Opportunities that have an easier time uncovering unmet needs: businesses with customers that have predictable and recurring buying patterns and are frequent users of the offering where it is easy to identify, locate and engage in a dialogue with them, e.g. to engage a business traveler on their preferences for laptops, mobile devices, internet service, or luggage, simply spend a couple of hours in an airport and you will be able to collect a wealth of information from a demographically and geographically diverse customer set
Explanation:
When considering your ability to identify the customer's unmet needs, consider the following items: 

  • If at all possible, design and develop your offering in partnership with initial customer(s) that are representative of your addressable market (otherwise you will have too narrowly defined your product or service) -- working in tandem with real customers to solve their unmet needs is vastly superior to developing an offering without that valuable input
  • Acquire a list of prospects and conduct a survey to determine their needs and current dissatisfaction 
  • Meet face-to-face with as many potential customer prospects as possible 
  • Consider attending an industry trade show in your target industry to size up competitive offerings and engage customer prospects in dialogs that will round out your market research
Key Principle: What is the ability to identify the customer’s needs that are under-served or not currently being met?
Why This Matters: The greater your ability to identify unmet needs, the better the opportunity. The greater your ability to identify unmet needs, the more precisely you can design and develop your offering to meet the customer demand, the easier it will be to acquire new customers, and the easier it will be to grow the opportunity.
answer1: Very low ability to identify unmet needs (limited understanding of the addressable market's needs)
answer2: Low ability to identify unmet needs (some understanding of 10% to 25% of the addressable market's needs)
answer3: Moderate ability to identify unmet needs (good understanding of 25% to 50% of the addressable market's needs)
answer4: High ability to identify unmet needs (deep understanding of 25% to 50% of the addressable market's needs)
answer5: Very high ability to identify unmet needs (deep understanding of >50% of the addressable market's needs)
name: Unmet Needs Identification

Definition: The risk that the value proposition of the product or service will not be easily understood, accepted, and adopted by potential customers.
Examples:
Mobile App Opportunity Example:

A mobile app's concepts risk depends upon the number of new concepts the user needs to learn or adapt in order to make the fullest use of the app's functionality.

Services Business Example:

The concept of outsourcing lawn care is well understood and therefore has very low concept risk. 

Other Examples Concept Risk:

  • Example of high concept risk: When application service providers (ASPs) or software as a service (SaaS) business models were first introduced in the 1998/1999 timeframe, they faced a high concept risk as they were introducing a new offering business model (software streamed to the user from a central source vs. being installed locally), a new pricing paradigm (renting software on a monthly basis vs. paying a one-time license fee), and was being taken to market by new companies. It was therefore a long difficult sales process to convince early adopters to try this new way of acquiring software.
  • Example of low concept risk: Any company with established customers and customer relationships that is adding a new offering to its lineup adjacent to existing offerings with a standard pricing model. The only thing that is different is a new offering from a trusted brand.
Explanation:
When considering the type of concept risk your opportunity carries, consider the following items and others like them that create high concept risk: 

  • Concept risk typically runs high when introducing a new product or service that "revolutionizes" the market and requires an "evangelism" type of sales process to "convert" customers to a new way of using the product or receiving the service 
  • Offerings with high concept risk usually have a much longer and more difficult sales cycle 
  • New pricing mechanisms usually increase the concept risk 
  • Companies that are new to an industry face higher than average concept risk as they lack a current customer base to experiment and survey during new product launches or price constructs
Key Principle: What is the risk that customers will not readily understand the value of the offering?
Why This Matters: The more difficult it is to articulate the value proposition, the more complex the product or service, the more unsophisticated the understanding of the customer decision making unit (DMU), and the more difficult the pricing mechanism, the more the concept risk. The lower the concept risk, the better the opportunity. The lower the concept risk, the easier it is for the customer to "get it" and the shorter the sales cycle.
answer1: Very high concept risk (new type of offering + new pricing model + new to the industry)
answer2: High concept risk (new offering + readily understood pricing + new to the  industry)
answer3: Moderate concept risk (readily understood offering + new pricing model + new to  industry)
answer4: Low concept risk (readily understood offering + readily understood pricing + new  to industry)
answer5: Very low concept risk (readily understood offering + readily understood pricing +  current industry participant)
name: Concept Risk

Caution: Long development time frames introduce the risk of new substitutes that have a better value proposition.
Definition: The total time it takes to bring your product to market or perfect your service so that your offering is ready to take to market.
Examples:
Mobile App Opportunity Example:

Because the mobile app market is moving so fast and there are so many apps already in the marketplace, short development timeframes are even more critical for success. Entrepreneurs should consider launching a minimum viable product to begin getting customer feedback and then rapidly developing enhancements rather than waiting to build out all app features in version 1.0.

Services Business Example:

Using our example of a lawn mowing business, the development time frame to develop the process for delivering the lawn mowing service is extremely short as it is very well defined and therefore there is little service development risk.

Example Opportunities with Long Development Timeframes: 

  • Drug therapies can have development time frames of up to 10 years long 
  • Enterprise software can have development time frames of up to 2 - 3 years long
Explanation:
When considering the development time frame of your potential venture, consider the following items: 

  • Research analogous products or services and their historical development history 
  • Survey experienced entrepreneurs or technicians that have already developed similar products or services to get their expert opinion
Key Principle: What is the total time to bring the offering to market from concept to full development?
Why This Matters: The shorter the development time frame, the better the opportunity. The shorter the development time frame, the less the risk, the lower the investment, the lower the development effort, the quicker the market feedback on the offering, and the shorter the path to Revenue.
answer1: Very long development time frames (>1 year)
answer2: Long development time frames (6 months – 1 year)
answer3: Moderate development time frames (3 months – 6 months)
answer4: Short development time frames (1 month - 3 months)
answer5: Very short development time frames (<1 month)
name: Development Time Frame

Definition: The ability to use technology in order to automate a business process and reduce costs, increase productivity, and/or increase quality.
Examples:
Mobile App Opportunity Example:

Since mobile app marketing and e-commerce processes are so well developed with the large app markets, most technology leverage will likely be in the area of app development with more advanced software development kits (SDKs) that automate and simplify app development. However, that is not a proprietary technology leverage since the same leverage would apply to all mobile app developers that use the latest SDK. Therefore, the opportunity to apply proprietary technology leverage to a mobile app opportunity may be difficult to acheive.

Services Business Example:

Using our example of a lawn mowing business, the ability to leverage technology is fairly low, unless a new technology can be deployed such as a robotic lawn mowing device that reduces the current labor content. Technology can be leveraged for the marketing functions and for back-office functions such as scheduling, billing and accounting, but this type of technology leverage impacts a much smaller portion of the overall cost structure compared to the potential operational benefit of automating the core business operation of mowing lawns. 

Example Opportunities with High Potential Technology Leverage: 

  • Automotive assembly and other manufacturing business that have replaced much of the labor content with automatic robots or computer numerical control (CNC) machines 
  • Manufacturing processes that adopt additive manufacturing (3D printing) technology that can leap ahead of competitors with more flexibilty, lower work in progress (WIP) and other advantages
  • E-commerce businesses that enable 24x7 transactions with little labor or customer service effort
  • Services ventures with a cost structure consisting primarily of labor expenses that can be automated, such as Finance and Accounting (F&A) outsourcers that invest in automated workflow process software to streamline processes and cut costs
Explanation:
When considering the technology leverage of your potential venture, consider the following items: 

  • Perform an activity-based analysis and detailed process map to determine what part of the overall offering can be automated
  • Research analogous companies and their overall cost structure and ability to leverage technology 
  • Research the amount of the cost structure than can potentially be "automated away" by technology 
  • Beware of the potential platform costs to build and maintain a mission-critical technology infrastructure
  • Look for opportunities where new (perhaps unrelated) technology has not yet been applied in the industry and where there are barriers to competitors utilizing the same technology (i.e. patents, marketing partnerships, etc.)
Key Principle: What is the ability to use technology to reduce costs, increase productivity and/or increase quality?
Why This Matters: The higher the amount of technology leverage, the better the opportunity. The higher the amount of technology leverage, the better the chance to create a proprietary "edge" in your market and create higher-than-average margins.
answer1: Very low technology leverage (technology can reduce <5% of the typical cost structure)
answer2: Low technology leverage (technology can reduce 5 – 10% of the typical cost structure)
answer3: Moderate technology leverage (technology can reduce 10 – 15% of the typical cost  structure)
answer4: High technology leverage (technology can reduce 15 – 20% of the typical cost structure)
answer5: Very high technology leverage (technology can reduce >20% of the typical cost structure)
name: Technology Leverage

Definition: The ability to deliver a product or service to your customers that provides value that is decidedly different than other products or services, not just in price, quality or service, but in performance or value created.
Examples:
Mobile App Opportunity Example:

The least distinctive moble apps are ones that charge for the app that allows you to manage a process or transaction, while the most distinctive mobile apps are free or low cost, but save users significant time and/or money that is quantifiable. For example, an app that merely allows you to find local restaurants by type and price adds some value, but an app that also pushes the customer money-saving coupons is more distinctive. And, most distinctive, would be an app that additionally allows you to pre-order the special of the day to have your meal ready when you arrive. The last app example saves the customer both time and money, while the first example, merely provided information.

Services Business Example:

There is little ability to create a distinctive value proposition by just mowing and trimming grass unless you add additional services into a unique service bundle. One example of creating a unique service would be to combine lawn care and watering by guaranteeing to cut the cost of the water bill through better overall turf management with the savings on water offsetting the cost of the lawn mowing. That would make it an easier value proposition to say yes to as a potential customer because their lawn mowing is basically free.

Examples of Offerings with Little Distinctiveness: commodities such as agricultural products or basic goods that are completely fungible; basic services such as janitorial, pool cleaning, etc.
Explanation:
When considering the value proposition distinctiveness of your potential venture's product or service, consider the following items: 

  • Research competitor's products or services and do a side-by-side comparison
  • Work to develop a value proposition that adds significantly more value to your target market than competitive or substitute offerings
Key Principle: Does the offering provide overall value to customers that is decidedly different and better than substitute offerings?
Why This Matters: The more distinctive your value proposition, the better the opportunity. The more distinctive your value proposition, the more defensible your market position, the easier the sale, the higher the barriers to exit the relationship and the lower the price pressure.
answer1: Very low value proposition distinctiveness (saves <10% of the customer's time or money)
answer2: Low value proposition distinctiveness (saves 10% - 25% of the customer's time or money)
answer3: Moderate value proposition distinctiveness (saves 25% - 50% of the customer's time or money)
answer4: High value proposition distinctiveness (saves 50% - 100% of the customer's time or money)
answer5: Very high value proposition distinctiveness (saves >100% of the customer's time or money)
name: Offering Distinctiveness

Definition: The average price of the average product or service increment in comparison to competitive or substitute offerings.
Examples:
Mobile App Opportunity Example:

Since the market has been established that many mobile apps have similar pricing (such as $0.99/app), the app that is offered at no charge, but has other revenue models (such as in-app upsells, advertising, etc.) can be positioned as an easier sell/download to price-conscious customers that are looking for free and want to try the app at no risk.

Services Business Example:

Since a lawn mowing business has high variable labor and fuel costs (see Fixed Costs) and therefore lacks economies of scale, it will be difficult to create a lower cost, lower price strategy without simply accepting lower margins, which is not a good strategy. As a result, the example lawnmowing business would most like have a price parity strategy of selling the services at comparable pricing and the focus should be to distinguish the service along other dimensions (see Value Proposition Distinctiveness, Quality Relative to Competitors and Service Relative to Competitors).

Example Low-Priced Strategies Relative to Competitors: 

  • Computer discounters that keep prices low through a lower-cost supply chain 
  • Big box discount retailers that keep prices low through tough negotiating and large-scale purchasing power 
  • Discount airlines that keep prices low through no frills service
Explanation:
When considering pricing, consider the folling items:

  • The lower your prices, the lower your margins (see Gross Margin), unless you have lower costs, the hallmark of a sucessful "value" strategy
  • For a low-price or value strategy to be effective, it should be consistent with the overall positioning as a company regarding the target customer and their needs, e.g. Wal-Mart sells low priced goods to price-sensitive shoppers
Key Principle: How does the price of the offering compare to competitive or substitute offerings?
Why This Matters: The lower the price (for comparable offerings) relative to competitors, the better the opportunity. The lower the price relative to competitors, the higher the value for your customers and the easier it is to grow your business.
answer1: Very high price relative to competitors (> 20% higher)
answer2: High price relative to competitors (5 – 10% higher)
answer3: Price parity relative to competitors (+/- 5%)
answer4: Low price relative to competitors (5 – 10% lower)
answer5: Very low price relative to competitors (> 20% lower)
name: Price Relative to Competitors

Definition: The ability to differentiate the quality of the product or service from competitors at a similar price.
Examples:
Mobile App Opportunity Example:

Mobile app markets have made this process relatively easy with customer ratings, but entrepreneurs should be sure to put processes in place to encourage customers to fill out the ratings and to follow up with those that give poor ratings to improve and protect the market reputation and relative ratings.

A one-star rating would score as a "Very low quality relative to competitors" while a five-star rating would score as a "Very high quality relative to competitors"

Services Business Example:

Arriving at a differentiated and tangible quality difference in a lawn mowing business can prove very difficult as there is little discernable difference between an "acceptable" lawn mowing service and a "high-quality" lawn mowing service. Most services offerings quality rating are based upon customer feedback in a similar fashion to the mobile app example above.
Explanation:
When considering the quality of your products or services relative to your competitors, consider the following items: 

  • Research quality benchmarks such as product returns, software bugs and customer satisfaction scores to see how you compare to your competitors or how you want to position the offering relative to competitive offerings 
  • Look for opportunities for side-by-side testing and comparisons to get an accurate read for the quality positioning
  • Product companies often offer extended warranties as proof of discernable quality difference
  • Service companies often offer money back guarantees with no strings attached as proof of a discernable quality difference
Key Principle: How does the quality of the offering compare to competitive offerings?
Why This Matters: The higher the quality compared to competitors, the better the opportunity. The higher the quality, the fewer complaints, the higher the customer satisfaction, the fewer the returns, and the better the market reputation.
answer1: Very low quality relative to competitors
answer2: Low quality relative to competitors
answer3: Same quality relative to competitors
answer4: High quality relative to competitors
answer5: Very high quality relative to competitors
name: Quality Relative to Competitors

Definition: The ability to deliver a higher level of service compared to your competitors at a similar price.
Examples: Using the example of a lawn mowing business, arriving at a differentiated and tangible service level difference can be somewhat difficult, but a few examples might be service guarantees that include "same-day" service whenever a customer calls for service or "next-day service" after a rain cancellation or other similar distinctive service levels that set your lawn mowing company apart from the competition.
Explanation:
When considering your service level, consider the following items: 

  • If you are targeting industries that are underserved when it comes to service, look for long lead times or wait times and high levels of customer dissatisfaction 
  • The higher your service level, the higher your costs and therefore, the lower your margins (see Gross Margin), unless your higher service level allows you to extract a premium price, which is typical of most successful "premier" service strategies 
  • For a high service strategy to be effective, it should be consistent with the overall positioning as a company regarding the target customer and their needs, e.g. premier service strategies primarily cater to customers that are service sensitive, but not price-sensitive
  • Measure the relative level of service based upon customer feedback if at all possible to have real market input
  • For pre-launch planning, choose a service level quality, but be sure to adjust the cost assumptions for a premier service level strategy
Key Principle: How does the service quality of the offering compare to competitive offerings?
Why This Matters: The higher the level of service relative to competitors, the better the opportunity. The higher the level of service relative to competitors, the higher the value for your customers, the higher your customer satisfaction, and the better your market reputation.
answer1: Very low service level relative to competitors
answer2: Very low service level relative to competitors
answer3: Service parity relative to competitors
answer4: High service level relative to competitors
answer5: Very high service level relative to competitors
name: Service Relative to Competitors
right:
Nordstroms or Four Seasons

Example businesses with a successful strategy of having a high service level relative to competitors: 

  • Nordstrom's, a department store well known for going the extra mile to serve customers 
  • Four Seasons Hotels, a high-end hotel chain known for a distinctively higher level of customer service than other hotels

Definition: The extent to which you have to sell a product or service in a short period of time or before a certain specified time, without the flexibility to store it or preserve it for later use.
Examples:
Mobile App Opportunity Example:

Mobile apps -- or any software for that matter -- is not perishable.

Services Business Example:

The perishability of lawn mowing service itself is low in that the service is not event based and does not expire, but there is perishability in the service delivery in that if a crew has capacity to mow ten lawns per day, but only has five lawns scheduled, the lost revenue opportunity cannot be recovered. The cost impact can be considerably lessened, however, if the crew can be released after completing five lawns without paying for the remainder of the day. 

Example Offerings with High Perishability: 

  • Travel services such where unsold hotel rooms, unsold airline seats, and unsold boat berths cannot be reclaimed once the night has passed, once the plane has taken off, or once the ship has sailed 
  • Services industries such as consulting, medical care, dental care, etc. where unfilled or cancelled appointments lead to a lost economic opportunity 
  • Entertainment services such as concerts, circuses, and movies where unsold event tickets expire soon after the event starts 
  • Processed food products that have short shelf lives and need to be sold prior to a certain expiration date 
  • Agricultural products such as ripe fruits and vegetables which must get to market quickly prior to spoiling
Explanation:
When considering the perishability of your offering, consider the following: 

  • Perishable products are products (like agricultural produce or food products) that go bad, spoil, or expire and have a limited timeframe in which to be sold
  • Perishable services are services (like concerts, flights, hotel rooms) that a definitive time after which the ability to sell the service is lost
Key Principle: To what extent does the offering need to be sold/delivered at a specified time without the ability to store or preserve it?
Why This Matters: The lower the perishability, the better the opportunity. The lower the perishability, the more the sales flexibility, the lower the capacity risk, and the less the price pressure because there is no "expiration".
answer1: Very high perishability (offering ages or expires within < 1 month)
answer2: High perishability (offering ages or expires between 1 - 6 months)
answer3: Moderate perishability (offering ages or expires between 6 - 12 months)
answer4: Low perishability (offering ages or expires after >12 months)
answer5: Very low perishability (offering never expires)
name: Perishability

Definition: The potential to enter new, adjacent markets where you can address similar needs with the existing offering or infrastructure.
Examples:
Mobile App Opportunity Example:

A mobile app that is built with scheduling, ordering, and payment processing features for one specific industry that ties into the retail point of sale (POS) system (let's say for restaurants) could potentially be revamped for another industry (let's say fitness clubs). The revamp may only include integrating with a different type of POS, but the features of scheduling and ordering services (such as personal trainers) and payment processing might be fully leverageable. If the fitness industry represents an additional 25% market opportunity and the revamp only requires 30% additional investment in app development, then the Adjacent Opportunity score would be "Moderate". Additional adjustments and expenses in the sales and marketing process would also be required to properly address the new market.

Services Business Example: 

For a lawn mowing business that serves homeowners, one adjacent opportunity is to eventually expand into offering lawn mowing services to commercial enterprises in addition to the initial target market of homeowners. The commercial lawn mowing market is typically based upon recurring services contracts and each job at office or apartment complexes are usually much larger than the typical home lawn mowing job. A few adjustments would have to be made to the sales and marketing process, but no adjustments would be required in terms of the offering itself.
Explanation:
When considering the availability of adjacent opportunities, consider the following items: 

  • The level of offering retrofitting necessary to address the adjacent market needs 
  • Explore all the differences in the customer needs, sales process, and operational requirements that may impact your business infrastructure as you attempt to address the adjacent opportunity
Key Principle: What is the potential to enter new, adjacent markets to address similar needs with the existing offering and infrastructure?
Why This Matters: The higher the availability of adjacent opportunities, the better the opportunity. The higher the availability of adjacent opportunities, the better the chance of growing your business and leveraging your existing offering development and infrastructure investment into new markets.
answer1: Very low availability of adjacent opportunities (no adjacent opportunities)
answer2: Low availability of adjacent opportunities (adjacent markets represent up to 25% growth with >50% change in the offering or infrastructure)
answer3: Moderate availability of adjacent opportunities (adjacent markets represent up to 50% growth with a 25% - 50% change in the offering or infrastructure)
answer4: High availability of adjacent opportunities (adjacent markets represent up to 50% growth with a 10% - 25% change in the offering or infrastructure)
answer5: Very high availability of adjacent opportunities (adjacent markets represent up to 100% growth with a <10% change in the offering or infrastructure)
name: Adjacent Opportunities

Definition: The ability to identify the name and contact information of those potential customers in your addressable market to enable you to market to them broadly through any channel or means.
Examples:
Services Business Example:

Using our example of a lawn mowing business, identifying the target market may be as easy as looking up the local county tax roll information on the county website to identify the homeowners for direct mail purposes. A ready to use mailing list of homeowners in your target market can likely be purchased directly from list owners such as Acxiom, InfoUSA, or USAData. Other methods are also often employed such as doorhangers, but be sure to analyze the effectiveness of all indirect methods employed.

Other Examples:

  • Example target markets with high ability to identify targets: Any homeowner-related market 
  • Example target markets with low ability to identify targets: Most corporate buyer-related markets where you are trying to identify the specific decision maker for certain types of purchases
Explanation:
When considering the ability to identify targets, consider the following items: 

  • Look for ways to market directly to prospects through multiple channels and multiple methods. The most effective marketing campaigns are 1) timed properly (the previous principle of In-Market Timing), 2) multi-purpose (direct and indirect), and 3) multi-channel (social media, online, email, direct mail, partners, and telemarketing)
  • While some forms of in-market timing provides both the timing and the actual prospect, many times you only know timing and not the actual prospect's contact information for a deeper marketing dialog
  • Explore social networking tools such as Twitter, Facebook, and LinkedIn to engage directly with prospects that volunteer data that identifies them and their preferences
  • Contact affiliates, marketing agencies, and list brokers and describe your target market to ascertain the availabilty of targeted prospects lists
Key Principle: How easy is it to identify the name and contact information of prospects in the addressable market?
Why This Matters: The higher the ability to identify targets or customer prospects, the better the opportunity. The higher the ability to identify targets, the better the chances of engaging with prospects and converting them into customers to grow your business.
answer1: Very low ability to identify targets (<10% of the addressable market at a cost of less than  1% of revenue)
answer2: Low ability to identify targets (10% - 25% of the addressable market at a cost of less than  1% of revenue)
answer3: Moderate ability to identify targets (25% - 50% of the addressable market at a cost of less  than 1% of revenue)
answer4: High ability to identify targets (50% - 75% of the addressable market at a cost of less than  1% of revenue)
answer5: Very high ability to identify targets (>75% of the addressable market at a cost of less than  1% of revenue)
name: Prospect Identification

Definition: The amount of market share concentrated among the largest customers within the addressable market, which is an indication of the market power of the largest customers.
Examples:
Mobile App Opportunity Example:

The mobile app addressable market has very low customer concentration because the target customers are individual mobile device users.

Services Business Example:

A lawn mowing business that is serving a fragmented homeowner or commercial customer market will have a very low degree of customer concentration.

Examples of High Customer Concentration: 

  • U.S. defense industry with only one department of defense and four service branches
  • U.S. automotive industry with only three large automotive OEMs 

Examples of Low Customer Concentration: 

  • Any consumer-focused market 
  • Any general business-focused market
Explanation:
When considering the degree of customer concentration, consider the following items: 

  • Use estimates where there is imperfect market information 
  • Survey prospective customers - receptionists are usually more than happy to explain how successful a company is in the marketplace
  • Company websites often have abundant information about their size and dominance
  • Sales literature, annual reports and other similar information should have indications of size or market share of the largest customers in your market 
  • One large customer with critical market mass with many small competitors is still a highly-concentrated customer market (think Wal-Mart and how they "punish" suppliers during price negotiations
  • To determine the degree of customer concentration in any market, start with the addressable market, try to identify the largest four customers and estimate their collective market share of the addressable market
Key Principle: What is the amount of market share concentrated among the largest customers in the addressable market?
Why This Matters: The less concentrated the customers in your potential market, the more "competitive" the customers and the better the opportunity. The less concentrated the customers, the easier it will be for you to negotiate favorably with customers that lack concentrated market power.
answer1: Very high degree of customer concentration (top 4 control >80% market share or largest  controls >40% market share)
answer2: High degree of customer concentration (top 4 control 50 – 80% market share or largest  controls 25 - 40%)
answer3: Moderate degree of customer concentration (top 4 control 25 - 50% market share or  largest controls 15 - 25%)
answer4: Low degree of customer concentration (top 4 control 10 - 25% market share or largest  controls 5 - 15%)
answer5: Very low degree of customer concentration (top 4 are not identifiable or control <10%  market share and the largest is not identifiable or controls <5% market share)
name: Customer Concentration

Definition: The ability to identify the timeframe in which the customer prospect is most likely to make the buying decision regarding your product or service.
Examples:
Mobile App Opportunity Example:

Mobile app companies should look to all available indicators of potential in-market timing. For example if you have a mobile app of "things to do in NYC" that includes discounts, ideas, and other valuable tips, you may consider ad placements on online map searches of NYC, hotel searches in the NYC area, airline ticket purchase into a NYC-area airport, etc. A cheap app that helps optimize an expensive trip might be an easy decision for prospective customers.

Services Business Example:

Identifying the in-market timing for a lawn mowing business will likely involve two distinct timetables: one event-based and one seasonal. Since many homeowners make decisions about service providers in a narrow window between just prior to buying their home and just after buying their home, the home purchase timing is the one event-based timing that will indicate whether or not a customer prospect is in market for your services. Additionally, at the beginning of each growing season, homeowners will likely make the choice for the season whether or not to outsource their lawn care, resulting in a seasonal decision made once each year. Of course others will decide throughout the season, but these two different timetables are most likely to indicate the "in market" timing. 

Other Examples:

  • Target markets with a high ability to identify in-market timing: any browsing or purchase activity that is directly related to your offering and any seasonal decision timing or any event-based decision that can quickly be identified and marketed around (a decision tied to the purchase of home, purchase of a car, wedding, birth of child, graduation of child, death, purchase of airline ticket, purchase of event ticket) 
  • Target markets with a low ability to identify in-market timing: any decision timing that is unpredictable, periodic, sporadic, or emergency-based will translate into decision timing that cannot be predicted or identified
Explanation:
When considering the ability to identify in market timing, consider the following items: 

  • For pre-purchase online browsing prospects, partner with online advertiser networks (such as Google) for ad placements that are consistent with key word searches that suggest the prospect is in market for your offering
  • For post purchase-based decision timing, analyze the decision process and research the availability of related purchases. For example, when Netflix was getting launched, they partnered with DVD player manufacturers to insert a Netflix coupon inside each box.
  • For event-based decision timing, analyze the decision process and research the availability of prospect lists or affiliate networks or strategic alliances that would give you access to prospects that are experiencing events that presage the decision timing of your offering, e.g. there are "just listed" prospects of homeowners that have recently listed their homes for sale with realtors, "recently purchased" prospects of homeowners that have recently purchased a home, "just married" prospects, etc.
  • For seasonal-based decision timing, try to determine the timing of the decision itself as it may precede the season, e.g. lawn care decisions may be made a month in advance of the beginning of the growing season
Key Principle: Is it possible to identify when a customer prospect is most likely to make a buying decision?
Why This Matters: The higher the ability to identify the in-market timing, the better the opportunity. The higher the ability to identify the in-market timing, the better the chances of being able to engage and close prospective customers and grow your business.
answer1: Very low ability to identify in-market timing (no ability to predict purchase behavior)
answer2: Low ability to identify in-market timing (<25% of purchase decisions are predictable)
answer3: Moderate ability to identify in-market timing (25% - 50% of purchase decisions are predictable)
answer4: High ability to identify in-market timing (50% - 75% of purchase decisions are predictable)
answer5: Very high ability to identify in-market timing (>75% of purchase decisions are predictable)
name: In-Market Timing
