Definition: The ability to drive sales via channel partners such as a referral network, distributors, resellers, wholesalers or retailers in order to more rapidly grow your business by leveraging the sales and marketing infrastructure of those channel partners.
Examples:
Mobile App Opportunity Example:

One of the powerful aspects of mobile apps is that the sales and marketing infrastructure is already built and the network already connected directly to mobile customers. The Revenue share paid to mobile app stores is an excellent value to reach the end customers without developing any of the typical infrastructure. While marketing investment is still required, mobile apps score very high on sales channels. Overall a mobile app opportunity would score with a very high ability to leverage sales channels.

Services Business Example:

Looking at a lawn mowing business example, there are several ways to create channel partners via referral networks or lead sharing with others such as realtors, home inspectors, and other home service providers. There are also online lead generation sites that homeowners search for service providers that provide some sales and marketing leverage via sales channels. Overall, a lawn mowing business would most likely score as having a moderate ability to leverage sales channels.

Other Examples of Sales Channels: 

  • Any manufactured product that is sold through brokers or wholesalers to retail distribution (there are many independent "rep" firms that represent a portfolio of products and have existing relationships with retail buyers)
  • Any software product that is sold through integration partners, value-added resellers (VARs), or app stores
Explanation:
When considering the ability to use sales channels, consider the following items: 

  • Look at analogous companies to discern their go-to-market strategy 
  • Analyze the various channels and the value chain to determine the value each channel participant is extracting from the various types of go-to-market channel relationships 
  • Look for other companies and networks that already have a relationship with your target customer
Key Principle: What is the ability to drive sales via channel partners such as referrals, distributors, resellers, wholesalers, or retailers?
Why This Matters: The more sales channels you can leverage, the better the opportunity. The more sales channels you can leverage, the easier it will be for you to grow your sales at a lower overall investment and lower risk.
answer1: Very low ability to leverage sales channels (<10% of sales via sales channels)
answer2: Low ability to leverage sales channels (10 – 25% of sales via sales channels)
answer3: Moderate ability to leverage sales channels (25 – 50% of sales via sales channels)
answer4: High ability to leverage sales channels (50 – 75% of sales via sales channels)
answer5: Very high ability to leverage sales channels (>75% of sales via sales channels)
name: Sales Channels

Definition: The ability to gain access to all of the decision makers that will influence the buying decision for your product or service.
Examples:
Mobile App Opportunity Example:

Since your DMU is usually only the mobile phone user, the DMU is considerable easier to engage with and market to. One exception is any underage game apps that will most likely have a DMU consisting of a child and a parent, but still it is a fairly simple DMU to market to.

Services Business Example:

Using our example of a lawn mowing business, the DMU is likely to be both the husband and the wife with one as the dominant decision-maker and the other an influencer. If in general the wife is the influencer and the husband is the final decision maker, but he is not available during normal business hours and only on Saturday mornings, the overall accessibility of the DMU is low since the size of your DMU is two rather than one and your direct sales efforts will be limited to only a few hours a week on Saturday mornings. Of course, there are still many indirect channels to pursue, but the DMU is still likely to be more complex than a simple consumer sale directly to one decision maker.

Other Examples:

  • Example of a highly accessible DMU: one person that is easy to contact and that is readily available during business hours or whenever you market to them
  • Example of an inaccessible DMU: several people from different organizations that are difficult to contact and are not readily available, such as a large non-profit purchase that involves the non-profit chain of command, as well as their independent board of directors and potentially even their large donor base for potential donations to fund the purchase - all resulting in a very complex sales process
Explanation:
When considering the accessibility of the decision making unit, consider the following items: 

  • The larger the decision making unit, the less accessible, as it becomes more difficult with a larger group of decision makers to get a unanimous purchase decision 
  • The higher the rank of any member of the decision making unit, the less accessible (CEOs are less accessible than purchasing agents) 
  • The more indirect the purchase behavior (such as e-commerce), the less the concern regarding DMU accessibility
  • Most business-to-business sales are much more complex and involve a much larger DMU than a business-to-consumer sale
Key Principle: How easy is it to gain access to all of the decision makers that will influence the buying decision?
Why This Matters: The Decision Making Unit, or “DMU" is comprised of all the people involved in the decision-making process from the customer's view point and is an indication of the overall complexity of the sales process. The higher the accessibility of the DMU, the better the opportunity. The higher the accessibility of the DMU, the better the chances of being able to engage with prospects, convert them into customers, and grow your business.
answer1: Very low accessibility of the DMU (all four issues: large DMU + multiple organizations +  lack of availability + difficult to contact)
answer2: Low accessibility of the DMU (any three of the four issues: large DMU + multiple  organizations + lack of availability + difficult to contact)
answer3: Moderate accessibility of the DMU (any two of the four issues)
answer4: High accessibility of the DMU (any one of the four issues)
answer5: Very high accessibility of the DMU (none of the four issues)
name: Customer Accessibility

Definition: The availability of substitute products or services that offer an alternative solutions in addition to offerings that are directly competitive.
Examples:
Mobile App Opportunity Example:

One of the challenges of uncovering the substitutes for your mobile app is the sheer volume of apps already available and new apps being released daily. There are so many competitive apps, substitutes, and alternative ways to deliver information and service via mobile devices that the noise in the market can make it difficult to determine the overall choice set of your target customer in your addressable market. One way to simplify the analysis is to analyze only the hightest rated apps in the app market that seem best suited to provide a meaningful alternative to your offering.

Services Business Example:

Using our lawn mowing business example, the availability of substitutes is high: the homeowner can simply mow their yard themselves. This availability of this substitute is higher if the homeowner already has all the equipment, while the availability of this substitute is somewhat lower if the homeowner has to procure the equipment prior to exercising the substitution. 

Example of a Low Availability of Substitutes:

A one-of-a-kind drug therapy where the therapy is enjoying patent protection and the only substitute is a very costly and invasive surgery that is only available from a few surgeons skilled enough to perform the procedure.
Explanation:
When considering the availability of substitutes, consider the following items: 

  • Consider the "fitness for use" of available substitutes 
  • Look for substitutes outside your normal industry, e.g. the threat that long-haul trucking played against railroads was high. Do not define your product or service too narrowly, e.g. railroads made the mistake of thinking they were railroads, but instead they were transportation companies and the substitutes were trucking firms 
  • Look for substitutes of a different nature, e.g. the threat that email played against the mail and package delivery industry 
  • The amount and/or accessibility of information to the decision making unit (DMU) during the decision-making process (if information on alternatives or substitutes is not readily available to the DMU, then those alternate products or services are not viable substitutes)
Key Principle: What is the availability of substitute offerings that also meet the customer’s needs?
Why This Matters: The lower the availability of substitutes, the better the opportunity. The lower the availability of substitutes, the fewer the customer choices and the more inelastic the demand.
answer1: Very high availability of substitutes
answer2: High availability of substitutes
answer3: Moderate availability of substitutes
answer4: Low availability of substitutes
answer5: Very low availability of substitutes
name: Substitutes
right: SWA pricing was compared to the cost of a bus ticket to other major Texas cities and they understood that they were not just competiting with other airlines, but other forms of transportation

Definition: The market effect when one customer draws in other customers via word of mouth because the value to that initial customer is higher if others also join the network.
Examples:
Mobile App Opportunity Example:

Mobile apps are most powerful when they leverage information or value from all other users of the same mobile app to deliver additional value to each additional customer, thereby creating a network effect. If a mobile app can achieve that benefit and deliver that value, then it would have a high network effect.

Services Business Example:

Using a lawn mowing business example, if you were able to offer a lower price to each customer in a neighborhood as more homeowners in the neighborhood become customers, you have created a network effect in that the more neighbors that join your lawn mowing "network" the more they benefit through cost savings. (There is often a lot of "windshield" time for lawn mowing companies with their crews driving from job to job, so mowing several yards in a row has obvious cost advantages.) The benefit would have to be properly communicated with prospective customers and each neighbor individually "sold" on the concept, but there is a potential for some network effect. 

Example Business Models with Well-Understood Network Effects: 

  • Social networks that "connect" users with a network and drive up the value of the network with more users, deeper connections, and more information
  • Any technology that requires at least two users on the same "platform" in order to work, e.g. think back to fax machines: one fax machine user has no value, two has some value, the more ubiquitous the adoption of fax machines, the more the value, and hence the network effect that forced rapid adoption.
Explanation:
When considering the ability to create a network effect, consider the following items: 

  • Does your product or service require two or more customer constituents in order for the value to be delivered?
  • Does the perceived value of one customer go up as more customers are added to the network?
  • Does the cost to the first customer go down as more customers are added to the network?
  • Does the customer get passionate about this type of product or service?
Key Principle: Does value to current customers increase when additional customers are sold?
Why This Matters: The higher the network effect, the better the opportunity. The higher the network effect, the more the word-of-mouth, the lower the cost of customer acquisition, the faster the growth and the more powerful the customer affinity with each other.
answer1: Very low network effect (none of the four network effect attributes: multiple customer requirement + perceived value increase + cost decrease + customer passion)
answer2: Low network effect (one of the four network effect attributes: multiple customer requirement + perceived value increase + cost decrease + customer passion)
answer3: Moderate network effect (two of the four network effect attributes: multiple customer requirement + perceived value increase + cost decrease + customer passion)
answer4: High network effect (three of the four network effect attributes: multiple customer requirement + perceived value increase + cost decrease + customer passion)
answer5: Very high network effect (none of the four network effect attributes: multiple customer requirement + perceived value increase + cost decrease + customer passion)
name: Network Effect

Definition: The average relative price of the average product or service increment (not in comparison to competitors or substitutes, but on a relative scale).
Examples:
One way to think about relative price point: if you were starting a business to sell cars and knew that it took the same amount of effort to sell a $500 clunker as it did to sell a $50,000 new car and you knew that the average contribution margin was 20% on each sale (clunker or new) which car business model would you rather focus on?

  • New car business model:
    • Revenue/car: $50,000
    • x 20% Contribution Margin
    • = $10,000
  • Used car (clunkner) business model:
    • Revenue/car: $500
    • x 20% Contribution Margin
    • = $100

Obviously the higher relative price point is much better for the same effort is all else was equal.
Explanation:
When considering the product or service price point, consider the following items: 

  • Your average price across all products or services and all customer segments 
  • For e-commerce businesses, generally the higher the product or service price point, the lower the cost of fulfillment as a percentage of the price (e.g. the shipping costs are the same for shipping a 1 lb. $500 item vs. shipping a 1 lb. $20 item, yet the $5 shipping costs represent only 1% of the $500 item and 25% of the $20 item)
Key Principle: What is the average price of the average offering?
Why This Matters: The higher the price point, the better the opportunity. The higher the price point, the more you can invest in the customer relationship, the higher the potential unit gross margin, and the higher the potential customer lifetime value.
answer1: Very low product or service price point (<$10)
answer2: Low product or service price point ($10 - $50)
answer3: Moderate product or service price point (<$50 - $500)
answer4: High product or service price point (<$500 - $5,000)
answer5: Very high product or service price point (>$5,000)
name: Price Point

Definition: The awareness of the customer to what they perceive to be the range of prices within which they will buy a particular product or service.
Examples:
Mobile App Opportunity Example:

It should be relatively easy to test the price sensitivity of a mobile apps by changing the price and watching purchase behavior of prospective customers that looked at the app in the app store. Mobile app developers should test the price sensitivity and settle on a price that optimizes Revenue, although the prospective customer can easily be very sensitive when the majority of apps are embracing a freemium business model or selling for only $.99.

Services Business Example:

Using our example of a lawn mowing business, the price sensitivity of your target customer can be determined during your customer surveys and competitor surveys and the price sensitivity will likely vary from one neighborhood demographic to another. Higher-end neighborhoods will likely be less price sensitive and more service and quality sensitive, whereas lower-end neighborhoods will likely be much more price sensitive. The customer set you focus on will determine the price sensitivity. 

Other Price Sensitivity Examples:

  • Example products or services that generally attract a price-sensitive customer set: basic necessities or commodities such as household products sold at stores like Wal-Mart to cost-conscious customers or services touted as “no-frills” services such as air travel on Southwest Airlines 
  • Example products or services that generally attract a price-insensitive customer set: luxury goods such expensive Rolex watches, where the customer actually feels better about wearing a $10,000 watch rather than a $7,000 watch (based upon the appeal of showing off their wealth as they talk about how much they spent), luxury services such as luxury hotels where a "sophisticated" traveler will not even consider a room for less than $500 per night, or emotionally-charged "once-in-a-lifetime" products such as engagement rings where there is a perception of the more he spent on her ring, the more he loves her. 
  • Example situations that generally result in less price sensitivity: "captive customer" situations such as the price of popcorn at a movie theater or the price of a meal at an airport where the customer has high demand, but little choice. Also, emergency situations where the customer makes quick decisions and cares little about price: no one stops to negotiate the cost of the ambulance ride.
Explanation:
Customers with high price sensitivity will exhibit purchasing behavior that is directly tied to pricing and affected by relatively small movements in price (a condition called an elastic price or price elasticity), whereas customers with low price sensitivity (inelastic price or price inelasticity) will exhibit behavior that is either not linked to price or will actually buy more as the price goes up, rather than less. The lower the price sensitivity of the customer, the better the opportunity. The lower the price sensitivity of the customer, the higher the price point, the more you can invest in the customer relationship and the higher the actual unit gross margin.

The degree of price sensitivity is often tied to market information. If a customer set gets frequent competitive offers for a non-differentiated offering, they will be much more sensitive to price because of their awareness of the "market" price.
Key Principle: How sensitive are customers to the pricing of the offering or its substitutes?
Why This Matters: The lower the price sensitivity of the customer, the better the opportunity. The lower the price sensitivity of the customer, the higher the price point, the more you can invest in the customer relationship, and the higher the actual unit gross margin.
answer1: Very high degree of price sensitivity (>25% of customers switch or prospects are lost due to a price change of <5%)
answer2: High degree of price sensitivity (10% - 25% of customers switch or prospects are lost due to a price change of 5% - 10%)
answer3: Moderate degree of price sensitivity (5% - 10% of customers switch or prospects are lost due to a price change of 5% - 10%)
answer4: Low degree of price sensitivity (<10% of customers switch or prospects are lost due to a price change of >10%)
answer5: Very low degree of price sensitivity (no customers switch or prospects are lost due to a price change of >10%)
name: Price Sensitivity

Definition: The average length of time of the overall sales process from initially contacting a customer prospect to finally making the sale.
Examples:
Mobile App Opportunity Example:

While there is an initial investment in getting a mobile app approved to be placed in the target mobile app store, once the app is in the app store and available for download, mobile apps enjoy an extremely low sales cycle where the cost of acquisition is directly linked to the purchase of the app.

Services Business Example:

For our example lawn mowing business, if sales and marketing process is primarily through direct mail and the total average time that elapsed between your direct mail campaigns and signing up the customer is 3 months, then your sales cycle is three months long. 

Other Examples of Sales Cycles:

  • Example business models with short sales cycles: most brand-name retail stores, where a customer walks in ready to buy, most e-commerce business models, where customers are searching online and often buy relatively quickly.
  • Example business models with long sales cycles: most complex sales processes such as enterprise software or IT outsourcing deals that have sales cycles that can last 12 to 24 months or more
Explanation:
When considering the length of the sales cycle, consider the following items: 

  • While the actual sales process itself may be short, consider the full cycle from initial advertising to closing the deal for businesses that are building a brand or a market presence for the first time in businesses such as a retail businesses 
  • Research competitors and analogous companies to benchmark their sales cycles by talking to their sales representatives or customer service personnel
  • For existing opportunities, capture and measure all key sales and marketing metrics to discern the sales cycle length and potential issues within the sales pipeline process
Key Principle: What is the average length of time that elapses between the initial contact with a prospect to the closing of the sale?
Why This Matters: The shorter the average sales cycle, the better the opportunity. The shorter the average sales cycle, the quicker the business can add customers, the quicker the opportunity can grow, and the less risk of the opportunity.
answer1: Very long sales cycle (> six months)
answer2: Long sales cycle (three to six months)
answer3: Moderate sales cycle (one to three months)
answer4: Short sales cycle (one week to one month)
answer5: Very short sales cycle (< one week)
name: Sales Cycle

Definition: The total sales and marketing costs to convert a prospect into a new customer.
Examples:
Mobile App Opportunity Example:

Most most apps are sold via mobile app stores with a clear cost of a Revenue share percentage, such as 30%, but other acquisition costs (such as advertising) must be added to that to Revenue share expense to arrive at the total acquisition cost per customer.

Services Business Example:

Using our lawn mowing business example, if you are spending $2,500 per month in your total marketing and sales expenses, including advertising, promotions, direct mail expenses, sales commissions, etc. to acquire 50 new customers each month, then your average customer acquisition cost would be $2,500 total cost/50 new customers = $50 acquisition cost per customer. 

Other Examples:

  • Business models with high customer acquisition costs: any large, complex sale such as aircraft engines, enterprise software, and large outsourcing contracts that require a long sales cycle, involve a large DMU, and with a high degree of face-to-face selling by a large sales team
  • Business models with low customer acquisition costs: any simple sale with a low price point of known and fungible items such as books, videos, and gadgets that experience a short sales cycle, involve a small DMU, and indirect sales methods such as e-commerce
Explanation:
When considering the customer acquisition cost, consider the following items: 

  • Customer acquisition costs are considerably higher for business models that require face-to-face direct selling than those that can be sold through e-commerce or telesales methods 
  • Customer acquisition costs are considerably higher for business models that require a long-distance direct sales effort rather than local market selling due to travel time and expense 
  • An easy analysis for an existing opportunity is to take the total sales and marketing cost (devoted to new customer acquisition, not just current account maintenance) for a period (say a month) and divide it by the number of new customers acquired in that same period
  • Compare organic customer acquisition costs to M&A-based customer acquisition costs to determine which method of acquisition is most efficient
Key Principle: How much are the total sales and marketing costs to convert a prospect into a new customer?
Why This Matters: The lower the customer acquisition cost, the better the opportunity. The lower the customer acquisition cost, the lower the up-front investment risk in each customer prospect and the higher the customer lifetime value.
answer1: Very high customer acquistion cost (>50% of the end-customer price of the offering)
answer2: High product customer acquistion cost  (35% - 50% of the end-customer price of the offering)
answer3: Moderate customer acquistion cost  (20% - 35% of the end-customer price of the offering)
answer4: Low customer acquistion cost  (10% - 20% of the end-customer price of the offering)
answer5: Very low customer acquisition cost  (<10% of the end-customer price of the offering)
name: Customer Acquisition Cost

Definition: The length of the average customer relationship -- typically associated with recurring revenue or repeat sales business models -- is indicative of the ability to experience repeat sales.
Examples:
Mobile App Opportunity Example:

Many successful mobile app business models have in-app purchase opportunities, ongoing revenue models, a social aspect, or a gamification aspect to the offering that extends the customer life.

Services Business Example:

Using our lawn mowing business example, if the average customer relationship lasted only one season of several months, the customer life would not be nearly as long as if the average customer relationship lasted five years. Customer life could be extended by offering an end-of-the season special if the customer signs up for the next season.

Example Business Models with Long Customer Lives: 

  • Large outsourcing contracts that often run ten years or more 
  • Real estate leases that often run five years or more 
  • Consumer goods with strong brands such as food and snack brands, e.g. Coca-Cola or Fritos Corn Chips or Starbucks and clothing brands such as Polo or Lands’ End that claim lifelong adherents after significant marketing investment in the brand
Explanation:
When considering the ability to create a longer customer life, consider the following items: 

  • Look for opportunities to create loyalty programs to keep customers coming back and thereby extending the average customer life, such as frequent flyer clubs, frequent purchase discounts, mobile loyalty apps, etc. 
  • Research competitors in an attempt to discern the length of their customer life
Key Principle: What is the length of the average customer relationship?
Why This Matters: The longer the customer life, the better the opportunity. The longer the customer life, the more the revenue per customer, the greater the leverage of the cost of acquiring the customer, and the higher the lifetime value of the customer.
answer1: Very short customer life (one-time sale)
answer2: Short customer life (<6 months)
answer3: Moderate customer life (6 months - 2 years)
answer4: Long customer life (2 years - 3 years)
answer5: Very long customer life (>3 years)
name: Customer Life

Definition: The costs that a customer experiences when they switch to another provider or supplier.
Examples:
Mobile App Opportunity Example:

Mobile apps have a very low switching cost in general and many mobile device users readily switch to other apps without hesitation because of the low costs. Switching costs can be increased if value is added to the user based upon the information the mobile app collects and delivers to them. For for ways of increasing the value of the app to the user over time in order to raise the switching costs due to a loss of information or value to the user.

Services Business Example:

Using our lawn mowing business example, the customer switching costs are very low since there is little commitment to one particular provider or another, there is little to no actual costs to switch, there is little knowledge loss when switching, and there is little to no hassle cost to switch. 

Examples of High Switching Costs: 

  • Switching costs from a PC to a Mac or vice versa are high due to the sunk costs of software investment and the knowledge of systems operation 
  • Switching costs from one life insurance carrier to another are high due to the hassle of filling out all the paper, getting a new medical examination, etc.
Explanation:
When considering the customer switching costs, consider the following items: 

  • Consider the hassle factor of switching as well as the actual cost, e.g. the homeowner switching costs for a maid service is much higher than a mowing service, since the maid potentially has a trusted relationship with the homeowner, a key to the home, the alarm code, schedule information, very specific cleaning instructions they’ve learned by trial and error over time, etc. 
  • Consider any potential knowledge loss that goes along with the switch, e.g. switching from one tax accountant to another means the loss of all the history and knowledge of your financial history 
  • If the customer has never switched before and does not understand the switching costs, they may exhibit behavior which indicates a low switching cost even when there are high switching costs
Key Principle: What cost does a customer experience when switching to a competitor or substitute offering?
Why This Matters: The higher the customer switching costs, the better the opportunity. The higher the customer switching costs, the lower the customer churn and the higher the customer profitability as customers are more committed to your offering.
answer1: Very low customer switching costs (<25% of the total monthly spend)
answer2: Low customer switching costs (25% - 50% of the total monthly spend)
answer3: Moderate customer switching costs (50% - 100% of the total monthly spend)
answer4: High customer switching costs (100% - 200% of the total monthly spend)
answer5: Very high customer switching costs (>200% of the total monthly spend)
name: Customer Switching Costs

Definition: The ability to expand the customer relationship from selling the initial product or service to selling additional products or services; sometimes called expanding the "wallet share" of the customer.
Examples:
Mobile App Opportunity Example:

A mobile app cross-sell opportunity might include selling other data and information to the customer and additional in-app purchase opportunities. Mobile app developers should spend time focusing on all the opportunities to add value to their target customer and create a pipeline of additional potential offerings to cross-sell beyond the initial app purchase.

Services Business Example:

Using our lawn mowing business example, once you have served your lawn mowing customer well and earned their trust, it should be substantially easier to sell them on other services for their home and yard such as sprinkler servicing, hedge trimming, and tree trimming.
Explanation:
When considering the ability to cross-sell additional products or services, consider the following items: 

  • A deep understanding of your customer is required to fully understand other the products and services that may be of interest to help them meet other needs
  • The cost of cross-selling additional products or services to an existing customer is usually far lower than the cost of acquiring a new customer
  • The ability to cross-sell goes up substantially if you have a long-term recurring revenue relationship with your customer base
Key Principle: What is the ability to expand the customer relationship from the initial sale to additional offerings?
Why This Matters: The higher the likelihood of cross-selling, the better the opportunity. The higher the likelihood of cross-selling, the more leverage you gain from the customer relationship, the higher the customer lifetime value, and the more profitable the relationship.
answer1: Very low ability to cross-sell additional products or services (< 10% of revenue potential from cross-sell activity)
answer2: Low ability to cross-sell additional products or services (10% - 20% of revenue potential from cross-sell activity)
answer3: Moderate ability to cross-sell additional products or services (20% - 30% of revenue potential from cross-sell activity)
answer4: High ability to cross-sell additional products or services (30% - 50% of revenue potential from cross-sell activity)
answer5: Very high ability to cross-sell additional products or services (> 50% of revenue potential from cross-sell activity)
name: Cross-Sell

Definition: The measure of the time intervals between purchases for repeat or recurring sales.
Examples:
Mobile App Opportunity Example:

Many mobile app business models are constructed around a one-time sale and download of a mobile app with no additional sales. Mobile app business plans should strive to add other offerings that include monthly subscriptions or other more frequent transactions to drive additional value through the acquired customer relationship.

Services Business Example:

Using our lawn mowing business example, it is typical to have your lawn mowed weekly during the mowing season, so although lawn mowing is seasonal, you would still likely have between 30 - 40 repeat sales every year for a very high sales frequency. 

Example Business Models with High Sales Frequency: 

  • Consumables will typically have a much higher frequency than durables, exemplified in the marketing strategy referred to as the "razor-razor blade" business model. In the days preceding disposable razors, the razor itself was an expensive durable steel razor that used steel blades which were changed frequently. A famous strategy employed by Gillette was to subsidize the cost of the razor (which had a proprietary design that only the Gillette razors fit) or even give the razor away in an effort to capture a high volume of much higher margin razor blades. Other consumables with a "razor-razor blade" strategy are inexpensive ink jet laser printers that are often sold for under $200, but require ink cartridges that sell for $75 or more. 
  • Any recurring services business models such as SaaSh software, business process outsourcing, or other recurring professional services that require ongoing work or processing of a frequent nature.
Explanation:
When considering the sales frequency of your offering, consider the following items: 

  • Whether or not the offering is recurring or a one-time sell 
  • Whether or not you can shift the business model strategy from a large one-time sell (such as a software license business model) to a monthly recurring revenue stream (such as a software-as-a-service (SaaS) business model)
  • Other competitive purchases your customers make - be sure to look at the entire "wallet share" and not just your sales projections or history, e.g. a customer may frequently stay at three or four different hotel brands when they travel, but any one hotel would not understand the full potential of the frequency of travel unless they got to know the customer better via surveys and direct contact
Key Principle: How frequently will the average customer purchase an offering?
Why This Matters: This attribute is distinct from customer life in that a customer with a ten year life that buys a product or service every five years is not nearly as valuable as a customer with a ten year life that buys a product or service every month. The higher the sales frequency, the better the opportunity. The higher the sales frequency, the stronger the potential customer relationship, and the higher the probability to leverage the relationship into additional products and services.
answer1: Very low sales frequency (one-time sale or less than once every five years)
answer2: Low sales frequency (every 1 - 5 years)
answer3: Moderate sales frequency (annually)
answer4: High sales frequency (monthly)
answer5: Very high sales frequency (weekly or more)
name: Sales Frequency

Definition: The type of customer relationship you are able to develop with your average customer ranging from a casual one-off, non-contractual relationship to a deeper contractual relationship to a committed, partner relationship.
Examples:
Mobile App Opportunity Example:

The low-cost and convenient nature of searching for, buying, and downloading a mobile app means very few mobile apps will be able to achieve a multi-year, contractual recurring revenue relationship with customers. An except is a mobile app that is developed in partnership with a much larger software ecosystem with such contracts and the mobile app piggybacks on the longer-term contracts.

Business Services Example:

Using our lawn mowing business example, it is very rare for a household lawn mowing customer to sign a service contract, but it is highly likely that a commercial customer such as an office building or apartment complex to sign a multi-year service agreement with built-in pricing escalation. You will build more value and stability into your lawn mowing company if you added commercial clients of a recurring contractual nature rather than household clients that, while they are recurring in terms of service intervals, are not contractual. 

Other Examples:

  • Example service businesses with deep customer relationships: Any services business that requires a customer investment in integration or set-up, any kind of service relationship that carries high switching costs, and any services business that requires a services contract. Examples include web hosting, software hosting, information processing, e-commerce hosting, and credit card processing. 
  • Example product businesses with deep relationships: Any product where the customer has to invest a considerable amount in any type of platform that often leads to a deeper, longer-lasting relationship.
Explanation:
When considering the type of customer relationship potential your business has, consider the following items: 

  • The value of the contract itself has a lot to do with the contract language, especially the Term and Termination language. Carefully construct services contracts and give great care as to how it is written. A "no out" contract except for "failure to cure" is much more valuable than a contract with an "out" for any reason upon a 30-day notice. 
  • The more you can "partner" with your customers in ways that tie them into your business model (such as cross-marketing each other's products or services), the deeper the relationship. The "Intel Inside" campaign where chip processor Intel promoted on behalf of the PC makers that used their processors was a very effective tool for Intel to deepen their relationship with their customer PC makers.
  • Look for ways to create "hooks" into the customer experience. For example, many new printers come with an offer to auto-ship a new print cartridge periodically or easy ordering online in an attempt to deepen the relationship.
Key Principle: How sticky is the relationship with the average customer?
Why This Matters: The deeper the customer relationship, the better the opportunity. The deeper the customer relationship, the more committed the customer, the more stable and predictable your revenue, the higher the customer lifetime value, and the more profitable the relationship.
answer1: Very shallow relationship type (no service contract, no initial investment, and no other commitment)
answer2: Shallow relationship type (no service contract, but a moderate initial investment or other moderate commitment)
answer3: Moderate relationship type (service contract with the standard “out” language and a moderate initial investment or other moderate commitment)
answer4: Deep relationship type (service contract with no “out” language and a significant initial investment or other commitment)
answer5: Very deep relationship type (multi-year service contract with no “out” language and a significant initial investment or other commitment)
name: Relationship Type
